articles.title: Consensus mechanism and mining-based attack
articles.description:
Blockchain technology is generally thought to be safe and adaptable, but the level of security is directly related to the amount of hash computer power that is used in maintaining it. Thus, it becomes more difficult for an attacker to hack the blockchain as the number of miners increases but no matter what, it can be attacked if left vulnerable. Meanwhile, blockchain technology can be attacked in a variety of ways. Here, emphasis will be laid on the different consensus mechanism and mining based attacks on a Blockchain;



1. Selfish Mining Attack

In many blockchains, the longest chain is deemed as the genuine edition of the database. So a selfish mining attacker can attempt to generate blocks in stealth mode on top of the existing chain. When he has a lead of two or more blocks over the current chain in the network, he has the tendency to publish it, which will be accepted as the new fact because it is the longest chain. He can do transactions on the public network before publishing his lengthy covert chain, which will allow him to undo the trade he just completed. This effectively gives the attacker an abrupt opportunity to execute double-spending based on the ability to establish a covert chain by accumulating enough block leads.




2. Mining Malware

Mining Malware usually mines cryptocurrencies for hackers using the CPU power of unwary users' computers. It's often used to drive cryptocurrency mining. In China, for example, it was reported that this malware had infected over a million Personal Computers, thereby authorizing attackers to generate more than 26 million tokens of various cryptocurrencies.




3. 51% Attack

When a miner or a group of miners controls 51 percent or more of the blockchain network's mining power, an attack is deemed to be possible. Though a 51 percent attack is extremely unlikely to occur in large networks, it is more likely to occur in small networks. However, when a group has absolute power over a blockchain network's transactions, it can block certain transactions or even undo older ones.




4. Timejack Attack

Intrinsic timing is obtained from the basic amount supplied by peer nodes in various blockchain networks, such as Bitcoin or Ethereum. For instance, you rely on your pals to tell you the time. The logic behind this attack is that if an attacker can add a large number of malicious entities to your friend list, he can have control over your time. Meanwhile, an Eclipse attack on the target node could be the first stage in this attack. Once this attack has been finalized on a target node, the target node will refuse to take blocks from the actual network since the timestamps of the blocks will not match their own. Because these transactions can't be sent to the actual blockchain network, the attacker can double-spend or conduct transactions with the targeted node.




5. Finney Attack

In the Finney attack, there is a likelihood for the attacker to double spend the money if he can mine a block with one of his transactions in it while staying anonymous. Thus, the attacker can transfer this previously transacted cash to a dealer if the unconfirmed transaction is accepted. Then, before the new transaction is confirmed on the network, the attacker can reveal the previously mined block that was kept secret.




6. Race Attack

This attack is usually considered as the truncated version of the Finney attack. In this attack, the attacker does not need to pre-mine the block with his transaction because he already has plans to double spend it. During this attack, the attacker sends a dealer, who is the casualty, an unconfirmed transaction while concurrently sending another transaction to the network. So, if the attacker is directly linked to the dealer's node, it is easy for him to launch the attack. This gives the dealer the impression that his transaction is the first, but the fact is that the attacker never sends it to the blockchain network in the first place.

articles.title: Byzantine fault tolerance (BFT)
articles.description:
How does Byzantine fault tolerance work?


Byzantine Fault Tolerance works by defining a set of rules to solve the problem of Byzantine generals satisfactorily. Achieving this goal is complex, as this type of failure involves no restriction. This situation makes the problem more complex and difficult to deal with. However, in many computer systems, this tolerance is a requirement. Therefore, to achieve this goal, a Byzantine fault-tolerant system must at least meet the following conditions:


  • Each process must be started with an undecided status (neither YES nor NO). At this point, the network proposes a series of deterministic values   applicable to the process.
  • To share values, a means of communication must be guaranteed. This is to display messages safely. The medium may also serve to talk and pick out the events unequivocally.
  • At this point, the nodes calculate the values   and go to a decision state (YES or NO). Each node must generate its state, which is part of a purely deterministic process.
  • Once decided, total and wins the state with the greatest number of favorable decisions.
  • Basic operation of a Byzantine fault-tolerant algorithm.


These four points define the Byzantine Fault Tolerance Algorithm
Byzantine fault tolerance can solve various problems. Among these, we will talk about some of the most relevant to understand a little more about its wide usefulness:


Basic 1: use in software compilers


A compiler Source code is one of the most complex computer tools that we can know. Compilers can convert the source code of a program into a binary capable of being executed by the computer. This means that they convert something close to human language (like C / C ++ or Go) into the machine or binary language.



Basic 2: Data storage systems


Another use case of Byzantine fault tolerance is the Data Storage Systems. Many database systems and even file systems implement it to improve the reliability of stored data. An example of this is the ZFS file system. This archiving system is capable of replicating advanced hashing, replication, deduplication, error correction, management, and storage of large amounts of data.



Basic 3: Avionics systems


This is the case with the aeronautical information management system. A system that operates in real-time and is tolerant of Byzantine faults.

Each of the aircraft's sensors communicates with command-and-control systems, providing information in real-time. Failure of a sensor must at no time result in catastrophic failure of the aircraft. To achieve this, Byzantine fault tolerance is used. This is to compensate for sensor data or damaged systems and ensure the safety of the aircraft.



Basic 4: blockchain consensus protocols


Consensus protocols in the blockchain like PoW tolerate Byzantine faults. These allow a distributed network to reach consensus under Byzantine conditions. When Satoshi Nakamoto designed Bitcoin, this kind of tolerance was taken into account. To do this, he created a series of rules and applied the PoW consensus protocol to create fault-tolerant Byzantine software. However, this tolerance is not 100%.


Despite this, PoW has proven to be one of the most secure and reliable implementations for blockchain networks. In this regard, the Proof of Work Consensus Algorithm, devised by Satoshi Nakamoto, is considered by many to be one of the best solutions to Byzantine faults. PoS and DPoS for their part, do not fully tolerate Byzantine faults, which is why they are usually supplemented by other security measures.




Advantages and disadvantages


Advantages

  • Ability to ensure accuracy of data and information, in distributed systems. This even in hostile scenarios for such tasks.
  • It solves the problem of processing information in heterogeneous environments.
  • High efficiency in terms of calculation and energy.
  • It offers implementations that have a positive impact on scalability if well built.
  • The more nodes that apply Byzantine fault tolerance, the more secure the model.

Disadvantages

  • Creating these solutions is complex. This can lock other security issues into your implementation.
  • Ensuring its proper functioning requires that the distribution of the system develops. The more nodes that apply the process, the more secure it is. But it also negatively impacts the scalability and bandwidth of the network.

articles.title: Zero knowledge proof (ZK)
articles.description:
Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZK-Proofs) are a concept with which one can provide evidence without further knowledge: One proves something to other actors without having to give them information about the proven things themselves. This process replaces trust or reputation in many places - and thus a function that neutral institutions take on today or that only emerges in a resilient manner over time. Technical solutions can soon provide instant security for this evidence. It has enormous potential for digitized business processes.

With Zero-Knowledge Proofs, there is always someone who proves something, the so-called prover, and the person who is proven something, the verifier. The advantage is obvious: You can do without middlemen who have to be paid or you can slow down a process. There are also other advantages: For example, the automated proof eliminates human and hardware errors. Ultimately, zk-proofs are based on calculations *, and they can be used to ensure that the other person has calculated correctly. In addition, no "trusted hardware", such as Intel SGX, has to be used. And finally, even on a compromised system, only proofs can be created that are either correct or are recognized as incorrect by the verifier. Of course, these statements do not apply equally to every zk-proof system. But some approaches offer almost everything.

A variety of zk-proofs are zkSNARKs. zkSNARK stands for "zero-knowledge succinct Non-Interactive Argument of Knowledge".
In short, this is a proof (Argument of Knowledge) that is short (Succinct) and not interactive (Non-Interactive). Non-interactive here means without interaction between the Prover and Verifier, beyond the sharing of the proof itself. Added to this is the "zero-knowledge" property described above, that is to say, that the verifier does not have to know input values ​​and/or output values.



Possible applications

ZK proofs can be used in many applications. They are particularly interesting in connection with blockchain technology. In this way, all advantages of public blockchains can be used without making sensitive (e.g. secret or personal) data public.
One example is one of the most famous use cases of blockchain, decentralized money. The zCash blockchain enables the completely anonymous sending of money, i.e neither the sender nor the recipient nor the amount of the transaction are known. (At the moment, by the way, not every transaction in zCash is anonymous, the option must be selected separately.) The whole thing runs based on zkSNARKs. 


The proofs guarantee that the sender actually has the money and that no new money was created by the transaction. Security about the impossibility of creating new money is achieved through the correct implementation of the "Trusted Setup" of zCash. 


On Ethereum, the whole thing can be taken even further thanks to the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM). Since the EVM is virtually Turing-complete and almost any program can be proven with SNARKs, there are hardly any limits to the use cases. Since the creation of proofs is still quite expensive, their size is currently still very limited. Proof of the correct rendering of an image or film in a decentralized environment would be a nice application that currently fails due to the complexity of the calculations.

articles.title: What is CRYPTOJACKING?
articles.description:
WHAT IS CRYPTOJACKING?


Cryptojacking is an attack where the attacker runs cryptocurrency-mining software on your hardware without your permission. The attacker holds the cryptocurrency and sells it for a profit, and you are stuck with high CPU usage and huge electricity bills.
Mining cryptocurrency involves complex math equations, which use a lot of CPU power. In a typical cryptojacking attack, the mining software will max out your PC's CPU. Your PC will carry out slower, use greater strength, and generate greater heat. You can hear its fans spinning to cool themselves. If it's a laptop, its battery will die fast. Even if it is a desktop, it will suck up more power and increase your electricity bill.

cryptojacking methods


There are three main ways for cryptocurrencies to maliciously select mine to mine. Let's skim thru them so you recognize how to better protect yourself against them.

  • Browser-based cryptojacking
This is when the hacker uses the IT infrastructure and directly attacks the web browser. They create a crypto mining script that is embedded in various websites. These scripts can be embedded in out-of-date WordPress plugins or advertisements where they run automatically when the code is downloaded to the user's computer. 
  • File-based cryptojacking
File-based cryptojacking begins with downloading malware that plays an executable file. A cryptomining script is spread around the IT infrastructure via this file. The most common way to do this is to spread malicious emails with links or attachments that seem legitimate enough for the user to click on them. If they click, the code is executed and downloads the crypto mining script to the user's computer to work in the background without their knowledge.
  • Cloud cryptojacking
Cloud cryptojacking is used when a hacker searches for API keys through an organization's code and files to gain access to its cloud services. They then amass unlimited CPU resources for crypto mining and as a result account costs increase significantly. Hackers illegally mine for currencies using this method as it helps them to move at a much faster rate. 


HOW TO DETECT CRYPTOJACKING?


Crypto mining scripts generated by hackers can be very difficult to detect and trace, which is why you need a highly alert IT team on 24/7 work for your organization's operations. Here are some common signs that will tell you something's wrong before it's too late and exercises that can help you detect cryptocurrency, watch out for these!


  • Overheating
Like any other intensive task, cryptojacking involves processing resources that can quickly overheat your computing device. Overheating will shorten the lifespan of your device and cause significant damage to it. Plus, overheating means the fans in your appliances will last longer than they should be to keep the system cool and running.
  • Decrease in performance
One of the major signs of cryptojacking is the lack of performance of your laptop, PC, mobile device, or tablet. If you observe an unexplained decrease in processing speed, call an IT technician immediately and have it checked. If you are running an organization, educate all your employees about their cybersecurity and the signs and symptoms they need to report. 
  • Regular website checks
Monitor your website and all its web pages regularly to ensure that there are no changes to the files and webpages on the webserver. This is an awesome way to stop a cryptojacking attack.
  • Monitor cpu usage
Analyze your CPU usage regularly using a Task Manager or Activity Monitor. An unreasonable increase in CPU usage means that there is something wrong going on. Especially for a website that doesn't have any media content that can drive traffic. 

PROTECTION AGAINST CRYPTOJACKING?


The following are some recommendations from security experts on preventing cryptojacking.


  • Maintain good safety hygiene
Establish solid security hygiene to reduce the risk of cryptojacking as all such attackers are opportunists and always prey on a vulnerable spot for wear. Hackers run many exploits on websites and get through whenever there is a patch.
  • Web filtering
Keep your web filtering tools up to date and ensure that your users are blocked from accessing a webpage that you identified as distributing cryptojacking scripts. 
  • Anti-crypto mining browser extension
Hooks into a crypto-miner web browser, to mine cash and deploy cryptojacking scripts. You can use browser extensions to avoid such crypto miners. Browser extensions such as No Coin, MinerBlock, and Anti Miner can be used. 
  • Disable JavaScript and Enable Ad-Blockers
Disabling JavaScript while browsing online will protect cryptojacking codes from infecting your device. And, ad-blockers will detect and block crypto-mining codes that are usually placed in web ads.

articles.title: What is a DAO?
articles.description:
What is a DAO?


DAO is the acronym for Decentralized Autonomous Organization - A set of anonymous people worldwide represented by rules encoded as a transparent computer program, making their own decisions without any external government influence.
This is what technological innovation had one as the digital currency industry continues to permeate society. All these people who are members of the organization work with rules embedded into the code on the blockchain, thus eliminating bureaucracy or hierarchy. This means that there is no need for managers.
Due to the paradigm shift in technology that has also affected the digital currency industry, the new generation of internet users is fashioning out to start social organizations that will bring about the exchange of values in a trusted environment.
Although there are automated trusted transactions and value exchanges in the blockchain, internet users want to organize themselves safely and effectively to work with like-minded folks around the globe.
Since that is the case, it can be said that Bitcoin is the first fully functional DAO. This is because its blockchain has a set of programmed rules that functions autonomously, under the control of a consensual protocol.
Bitcoin has been successful, but some had issues with their setup codes. One such example is the German startup slock that launched the creatively named "The DAO" to support their decentralized version of Airbnb. 
After its crowdfunding campaign generated over $150 million worth of Ethereum, it couldn't stay afloat because the code they used in the DAO had certain issues. This gave hackers field day as they made away in June 2016 with $50 million worth of Ethereum from the DAO before it was stopped.
Many technology startups have learned from these costly errors as the trend continues to emerge.
The development of more Decentralized Finance (DeFi) has eventually led to a rise in renewed interest in DAOs.
This write-up might not expatiate about their background and characteristics to appreciate, but the fact remains that the trend is moving away from the traditional forms of organization in the finance industry.



Why is DAO different?


As stated earlier, since DAO's financial transactions and rules are recorded on a blockchain, there is the elimination of a third party in a financial transaction. The network simplifies those transactions through smart contracts, which are the organization's rules and holds their storage. 
In this way, no one can edit the rules without people noticing because DAOs are transparent and public. 
Unlike traditional companies, DAOs are democratic. There is no one-person show here. Decisions are made after all the members of a DAO have voted for any changes to be implemented.
Another unique thing about the DAOs is that the funding is mainly through crowdfunding that issues tokens as the governance is based on community. The traditional companies' management is done by some set of executives, Board of Directors, activist investors. etc.
Traditional companies do keep some of their dealing secrets while DAOs' operations are fully transparent and global.

articles.title: Delayed proof of work
articles.description:
Meaning of Delayed proof of work

Proof of Work is the algorithm that validates the creation of new blocks on the blockchain. This is the key element in Bitcoin mining and it is what allows many money systems that work with the blockchain to free themselves from middlemen. It is also what secures an entire blockchain network and protects it from fraud, computer attacks, and spam.

At the heart of the blockchain

To understand its role, you must first remember the overall functioning of blockchain and mining. This information chain is both a permanent register of all the transactions that have already been carried out with it and at the same time a transfer tool. It requires powerful machines capable of solving complex calculations to ensure that none of this data can be changed. The work of these machines is called mining.
The information is transmitted in blocks that must be digitally validated by minors. When a transaction is carried out, it is recorded on each of the thousands of copies of the blockchain present in the world. Each copy is a perfectly identical record of all transactions.



Validate blocks 

For a block to be validated by network participants, miners must complete a proof of work covering all data in the block. Proof of work is the algorithmic process of discovering the number that "frees" the block. This number, called a “hash”, must be difficult to find, but easy to verify, in terms of computer calculation, by any user on a network.
The difficulty of this process is adjusted to limit the rate of generation of new blocks by the network to one every 10 minutes. Due to the very low probability of a successful build, it is impossible to predict which computer will be able to generate the next block.
The most widely used proof of work system is based on the SHA-256 cryptographic function, an algorithm originally designed by the NSA. It was introduced to the cryptocurrency world by Satoshi Nakamoto for the creation of Bitcoin. Among the other hashing algorithms used for proof of work, there is  Scrypt,  Blake-256,  CryptoNight,  HEFTY1,  Quark,  SHA-3,  scrypt-jane ...



Security

The PoW (Proof of Work) method is a cryptographic process that allows very high data security. For a block to be valid, it must contain all of the data contained in the previous block as well as the work that was done to bring it to life. Changing a block can only be done by creating a new block containing the data of its predecessor. This process protects the blockchain from any tampering.
This hash difficulty - this difficulty finding the number to create the block - is also what protects the data in the chain. Proof of work can deter denial of service (DoS) attacks. The computer that wants to perform a particular service will have to solve a very specific mathematical problem, a proof-of-work puzzle before it can use that service. In the context of a hack, individuals who wish to hijack a transaction would have to ask their machines to perform an enormous computation effort. This effort is normally enough to put off pirates.
But one more point makes proof of work make the blockchain even more secure: validation by other users. For a block to be validated, all copies of the hash must be identical. The hash is difficult to find, but it is easily verified. If one copy of the hash is different from all the others on the blockchain, the network automatically rejects the transaction that does not match the rest. This is what prevents fraud. Fraudsters can't tamper with the system until their copy of the blockchain matches that of the rest of the users.



No intermediary

The other great advantage of this cryptographic method is that it allows free use of intermediaries and avoids centralized management. Proof of work keeps track of every transfer: it does the work of a third party, such as a bank or transfer agency. The algorithm verifies transactions and allows strangers to trade digital goods without requiring proof of trust from the recipient. This proof of trust was once in the hands of banking organizations, it now passes into the hands of the blockchain.
This removal of intermediaries is likely to change many industries in the future. In the context of cryptocurrencies, the absence of third parties could put an end to the centralization of banking power. Exchanges would take place directly from one user to another and banks would lose their reason for existing. But this existence is a double-edged sword.
On the one hand, this proof of work could significantly reduce the costs of money transfers and weaken the power of banking institutions. Blockchain technology will save millions of people time and money while giving them more direct control over their assets. Individuals will be the only people in charge of their assets. But on the other hand, this advent could cause the loss of many jobs. This automation of work would create a global unemployment problem.



Cumbersome operation

The main problem with this method of validating transactions is its cumbersome operation. Proof of labor, which requires a worldwide consensus from every node at the blockchain, requires a considerable amount of energy. This algorithm asks each node to solve a cryptographic puzzle. This puzzle is solved by the miners who enter a kind of competition from which the winner comes out with a reward in Bitcoin. This reward is granted to him when he finds the hash that will allow the creation of a new block.
if we compare it with figures from the International Energy Agency (IEA). An expense that would supply several million homes.


Centralization

The enormous energy consumption that proof of work demands is also an obstacle to one of the ideological foundations of blockchain: decentralization. By eliminating intermediaries and allowing peer-to-peer (peer-to-peer) exchanges, the blockchain favored the emergence of a decentralized currency. The increase in the cost of implementing the PoW came to oppose this utopia of decentralization.
Currently, only large wallets, mining farms, and mining pools can still afford to mine. The power to enforce the proof of work of cryptocurrencies is held by a large handful of individuals, which is the hallmark of centralization. This is one of the reasons why members of blockchain communities are currently thinking about developing new methods of operation. Proof of stake is one of them.
To adopt these new methods, the community of the currency concerned must coordinate. As long as these users do not choose to forker their currency, it will continue to work with proof of work.

articles.title: What is uniswap and how does it work?
articles.description:
Uniswap is an Ethereum-based decentralized trading system. To be more specific, it is a protocol for automatic liquidity management. There is no need for an order book or a centralized party to execute transactions. Uniswap enables users to trade directly, with a high degree of decentralization and resilience to censorship.

How Does The Uniswap System Work?

Uniswap departs from conventional digital exchange architecture in that it lacks an order book. It operates on the basis of a design known as Constant Product Market Maker, which is a variation of the Automated Market Maker concept (AMM).
Automated market makers (AMMs) are smart contracts that maintain liquidity reserves (or liquidity pools) against which traders may trade. Liquidity providers finance these reserves. A liquidity provider is anybody who puts an equal value of two tokens into the pool. In exchange, traders pay the pool a fee, which is subsequently allocated among liquidity providers based on their pool share. Let's take a closer look at how this works.
By depositing an equal value of two tokens, liquidity providers establish a market. These may either be two ERC-20 tokens or one ETH and one ERC-20 token. Although stablecoins such as DAI, USDC, or USDT are often used in these pools, they are not required. Liquidity providers get "liquidity tokens" in exchange for their part of the overall liquidity pool. These liquidity tokens may be redeemed for the portion of the pool they represent

What Makes Uniswap So Unique?

The primary way in which Uniswap differs from other decentralized exchanges is that it employs a pricing method known as the "Constant Product Market Maker Model.
Uniswap may be used to exchange any ERC20 token by financing it with the equal amount of ETH and the ERC20 token being swapped. For instance, if you wanted to establish an exchange for the cryptocurrency Durian Token, you would create a new Uniswap smart contract for Durian Token and populate it with $10 worth of Durian Token and $10 worth of Ethereum.
Uniswap is unique in that, rather than linking buyers and sellers to decide the price of Durian Token, it utilizes a constant equation: x * y = k.

Is Uniswap a good exchange?

The term "flat fees" refers to the exchange charging the same fee to both the taker and the manufacturer. This exchange charges a flat 0.30% commission on all trades. This is somewhat more than the worldwide average for the industry. Thus, in terms of trading costs, Uniswap offers a competitive offering. UniSwap is without a doubt the most popular decentralized exchange (DEX) currently available. Unlike centralized exchanges, which provide a far more limited and curated range of tokens, virtually anybody may create and trade a currency on UniSwap.

Concluding Remarks

Uniswap is a cutting-edge Ethereum-based trading system. It enables anybody with an Ethereum wallet to trade tokens without the need for a third party to intervene.
While this system does have certain limits, it has some interesting potential implications for the future of trustless token exchanging. Once Ethereum 2.0's scaling solutions are implemented, Uniswap is expected to benefit as well.

articles.title: What is Tor?
articles.description:
If you have a fairly solid knowledge of I2P, then you probably have an idea of what Tor is. Essentially, they both work with that same goal in mind, and they are similar, with one of the main differences being that Tor has been on the scene a little bit longer than I2p.
It is often referred to as the world’s strongest tool for privacy. Over the years, Tor’s users have grown massively all over the world, so it only makes sense that we would want to know more about it, how it was created, and its uses. Let’s start with what Tor is.

Tor

Tor is a dark web browser that works as a free open-source software that offers anonymous communication on the internet for its users. It first appeared 18 years ago on 20th September 2002 to be precise. The official developer for Tor is The Tor Project, a non-profit organization that does a lot of research concerning the privacy of internet users and anonymous communication online.

How Does Tor work?

As you already know, Tor is an anonymous web browser.  The system bounces the traffic and users through relays. This way, it is very difficult for anyone to locate a user or identify where the information is coming from to be successful.
When you use the Tor browser, the browser connects to any of the entry nodes, then that traffic gets bounced off through a relay that is selected randomly, and then it throws out the traffic through the last exit node.
The Tor browser is highly accessible, and it can be downloaded either for your desktop, iPhone, or android, with varying platforms offering the application for download. The people handling the Tor project realized that many people in developing countries use Tor mostly on their mobile phones, so they spent a lot of time developing the mobile version to make sure it functions effectively.

What Can Tor Be Used For?

1. It protects you from tracking

Whether you know it or not, a reasonable number of people and organizations are looking for ways to get vital information about you, like your location and your online browsing habits. When Tor was launched in 2002, they made it clear that the browser was designed to protect individuals from corporations looking for ways to invade the privacy of internet users. When you use the Tor browser, your activities will be hidden from people who might be looking for ways to track you.

2. It keeps your activities private from excessive advertisement

Websites and ads are now like hands and gloves. They are so immersed in each other that you can’t separate them, but excessive ads can be annoying, so with Tor, your online identity can be hidden from websites and advertisers.

3. It prevents censorship

Governments and private organizations use censorship to suppress the speech and public communication of the masses. Most times, they do this because they believe that the information or content is objectionable. Users that want a way to avoid censorship from the government and other institutions will find that Tor is a very helpful browsing platform. Tor is a very good option for users that want to evade censorship in some countries around the world.

Final Words

Tor is favored by users all over the world. Still, it is not without some flaws. Generally, browsing with Tor is much slower than the average browser, and this is because of the relays used to bounce off users' and websites’ traffic. Another defect is that it blocks some browser plugins.

articles.title: What is symmetric key cryptography?
articles.description:
Symmetric key cryptography is an encryption technology that is capable of encrypting and decrypting communications using the same key. It is also known as symmetric encryption. This sort of data encoding has been frequently used in recent decades to enable secret communication between governments and militaries. The algorithms are also currently utilized in several computer systems to improve data security. Typical examples of this algorithm include AES, DES, 3DES, among many others.


How Symmetric Key Cryptography Operates

In symmetric encryption methods, a single code is usually derived between two or more users. Using the same code, the plaintext, which often denotes the message or piece of data being encoded, is encrypted and decrypted. Encryption is usually achieved by sending plaintext via a cipher, which helps in generating ciphertext.
If the encryption technique is powerful enough, the only way of reading or accessing the information which is contained in the ciphertext is by using the associated key to decrypt it. The intricacies of brute-forcing symmetric encryption methods are determined by the difficulty of randomly guessing the right key.
It's worth noting that guessing a 128-bit key with standard computer hardware would take billions of years. Therefore, the more difficult it is to crack an encryption key, the broader it is. Meanwhile, 256-bit keys are frequently thought to be exceptionally secure and theoretically impervious to quantum computer brute force attacks.

Uses in Modern Computer Systems

Symmetric key cryptography is used for various reasons in modern computer systems. For strengthening data security and user privacy, many advanced computer systems employ the use of symmetric key cryptography technologies to achieve that. The Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) is a common one, and it's utilized in both secure messaging apps and cloud storage.
In addition to software applications, AES can be directly implemented into computer hardware. The AES 256 is a variant of the Advanced Encryption Standard with a key size of 256 bits that are often employed in hardware-based symmetric encryption methods. It's important to note that Bitcoin's blockchain does not use encryption, contrary to widespread misconception. Instead, it uses the Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Method, a type of digital signature method that creates digital signatures without even encrypting them.

Pros and Cons

There are numerous advantages to using symmetric key cryptography. First, they provide a reasonable level of security which is quite massive. The security of symmetric encryption can be improved by expanding key lengths. For every bit added to the length of the symmetric key, the intricacies of cracking encryption using a brute force attack double exponentially. Symmetric key cryptography can also be used to quickly encrypt and decode messages. The greater simplicity of symmetric systems is also a logistical benefit, as they require less computing power than asymmetric systems.
While symmetric encryption offers numerous benefits, it does have one significant issue. It's because exchanging encryption and decryption keys in it is inherently challenging. When shared over an unsecured connection, these keys are vulnerable to being intercepted by malicious third parties. Therefore, if a hacker acquires access to a specific symmetric key, the security of any data encrypted with that key is usually threatened. Thus, to combat this issue, many web protocols use a combination of symmetric and asymmetric encryption for generating safe connections.

Conclusion

Due to its high speed, simplicity, and anonymity, symmetric-key cryptography is often used in applications ranging from encrypting internet traffic to securing data that are stored on cloud servers.
Symmetric key cryptography techniques are still an important aspect of modern computer security, even though they are frequently employed in conjunction with asymmetric encryption to address the difficulty of securely communicating keys. It's a technology that's evolving and it's still going to be used in many other fields because of how relevant it is.

articles.title: What you need to know about I2P invisible internet project
articles.description:
Yes, you can now be invincible on the internet and believe it when we say it’s not magic. I2P or Invincible Internet Project is a platform or network that can make you appear invincible on the internet when you don’t want to be tracked or for when you just want your privacy. It is mostly used by people on the internet who choose to be discrete, and it is made up of peers, which are also called routers. You're are going to discover what you need to know about I2P, starting from what it is to the basics of how it works and then what it can be used for. Read on.


What is an Internet Project?

The invincible Internet project is also known as I2P, and it is a private network that is encrypted to offer privacy to its users and also protect the activity and location. It is a decentralized, anonymous network, built mainly to offer privacy and an anonymous status to its users. You can browse, send emails, host websites, and even spend time chatting anonymously once you are connected to the network.



How Does it Work?

First off, I2P is Peer-Peer. It works when people offer their bandwidth to other people in the network. This network layer has software and a router that connects you and other users of the network to the applications. It uses cryptography to build tunnels that use transports to hide the traffic. All the connections are end-to-end encrypted. The cryptographic addresses are self-authenticating and work in such a way that they only belong to the user who generated them in the first place.

The network makes every user a node. Through this node, traffic can then be routed and encrypted. One-way connections can be provided for the computers in the network.



Uses of the invincible internet project

1. It protects you from getting tracked or having your data collected.
When you make use of I2P, you don’t have to worry about being tracked on the internet or even having your data collected. The Invincible Internet Project can protect your information to protect you from hackers and people prowling on the internet looking for how to get your vital information.
2. It protects your privacy
How the Invincible Internet Project works is that it hides the server from the user, and it also hides the user from the server. Picture it like an invincible layer that lies on top of the internet, not interacting directly with it. This way, the encryption will make people unable to know where the traffic is coming or going.
3. It allows you to be discrete
Let’s be honest. Sometimes, we just want to lay low on the internet for one reason or the other. The Invincible Internet Project can be used by people who are doing sensitive work on the internet and do not want to be seen on the internet, thereby seeking discretion.



Final Words

Even though the Invincible Internet project practically makes you invincible, it does not entirely leave the traffic as some people might think. 

To achieve the privacy and discretion that it offers its users, the Invincible Internet Project makes use of out proxies to the internet, which is a service that is run by volunteers. 

The Invincible Internet project might be a great option for users who desire privacy on the internet, but it is not the only option. Some other applications and networks also work towards communicating privately on the internet. Some of them are Tor and Freenet, amongst others.

articles.title: Delegated proof of stake
articles.description:
What does Deligated Proof of Stake (DPoS) mean?


Delegated Proof of Stake (DPoS) is a verification and consensus mechanism in the blockchain. It competes with other proof of work and proof of stake models as a way to verify transactions and promote blockchain organization.


How Techopedia Explains Delegated Proof of Stake (DPoS)


In a delegated proof of interest system, stakeholders build consensus according to their amount in a cryptocurrency system. Experts point out that some of the value of delegated proof of stake is scalability and speed, and that one advantage is the streamlining of digital transactions. However, the issues of security and inequality revolve around the idea that delegated proof of stake centralizes decision-making in the hands of the richest few in a given cryptocurrency market. Some worry that a delegated proof of stake model would result in large stakeholders forming cartels, which could lead to a variety of bad market actions.


How does Proof of Stake work?

  • Proof of Stake is mostly based on the nodes in the network. Transactions are sent to the nodes to be bundled in blocks and verified. A consensus mechanism then decides which node or nodes will select the transactions to be verified.

  • Which nodes are determined can depend on various factors? Some blockchains only have a limited, small number of validators that are elected by delegates. These delegates use their stake to appoint a validator and receive a block reward for this.

  • Mechanisms are often introduced to recognize and punish harmful behavior. Some blockchains use a reputation model that punishes untrustworthy actors. The code that defines how the Proof of Stake works is often complex.


Proof of Stake benefits

  • Compared to Proof of Work (PoW), Proof of Stake causes significantly lower energy consumption. At PoW, new blocks have to be mined by validating or solving difficult tasks. As with Bitcoin, this requires enormous computing power, which results in high energy consumption. The times when you could mine Bitcoin with an old graphics card that you no longer need are long gone. Anyone who wants to participate in mining today not only has to pay for high electricity bills but also has to be able to afford expensive, specialized hardware. Private miners compete with companies that mine on a large scale. The mining farms are often located in countries with low electricity costs.

  • Participating in a Proof of Stake Blockchain is easier and cheaper. In many cases, it is sufficient to buy the cryptocurrency and deposit it. With some blockchains, however, Proof of Stake is only possible from a certain height. With DASH, for example, you need 1,000 DASH to operate a master node. Other cryptocurrencies allow small amounts to be staked.

  • With Proof of Stake, the network is not in danger of being manipulated by a few miners who have the most hash power.

Cons of Proof of Stake

  • With certain blockchains, the size of the stake decides which actor is selected to create a new block. If a few players, such as the founders or early investors, hold very large shares, this can be to the disadvantage of small stakes. In addition, large participants retain the majority of votes and thus control over the development of the blockchain. This essentially contradicts the idea of   decentralization and the idea that a blockchain is supported by many small players.

  • One counter-argument concerns what is being accused of Proof of Work: the high demands on the hardware. The hardware is there to solve difficult mathematical tasks that require enormous computing power. Since this does not apply to Proof of Stake, there is no barrier for those who want to manipulate the network.

articles.title: What is an eclipse attack?
articles.description:
An eclipse attack is a type of denial-of-service (DoS) attack that can affect peer-to-peer
(P2P)blockchains. Though it is lesser known than other exploits such as 51% attacks, it is
notable as being able to deal similar damage with fewer resources.


Bitcoin’s network


Before explaining Eclipse attacks it is first necessary to explain some aspects of nodes
in blockchain networks, we’ll use Bitcoin’s network as a specific example for the purposes of this
article. Bitcoin is a P2P network where nodes connect to multiple other nodes for the purposes
of communicating information on transactions and blocks. Each node receives from and
transmits to a certain number of other nodes, with defaults set at a maximum 117 incoming
connections and 8 outgoing connections. A node can only know what its other connected nodes
are telling it.


What is an eclipse attack?

An eclipse attack happens when an attacker completely controls the flow of information
to a node by controlling all of its connected nodes. This allows the attacker to isolate the node
from the rest of the chain, creating a fork that will collect different information from the main
chain. The victim nodes will not learn about blocks in the outside network, and the outside
network will not learn about blocks within the victim nodes.


51%-like effects

This situation allows for an attacker to conduct an attack similar to a 51% attack without
actually controlling 51% of the total hash power.
The attacker may separate miner nodes so they can not communicate. Consider a
network split in 2. If the attacker has more mining power than either side of the network, they
now have 51% attack powers from the perspective of either side. The attacker may now spend
on one side of the network, and recombine the other side of the chain onto the network if that
side has more blocks. This uncles the blocks the attacker’s transaction happened in, even
though they may have already passed adequate confirmations from a merchant’s perspective.
The transaction now did not happen from the perspective of the blockchain, and may be
double-spent.


Eclipse attack method example on previous Bitcoin versions

Bitcoin has patched most problems that allowed for the potential of Eclipse attacks,

however this is a method that would have worked in previous versions.

1. Fill node peer table, a node’s list of potential peer connections, with attacker nodes. The
peer tables were biased towards selecting fresh IPs, and so this could be done by
spamming fresh IP nodes.

2. Force node restart. A node would connect only to attacker nodes due to being the only
options in their peer table. Restarting can be done through a few routes, such as waiting
for known software updates, Denial of Service Attacks, or waiting for power/network
problems. Bitcoin nodes statistically go offline frequently. Restarting fills all outgoing
connections by itself, which itself makes filling incoming connections trivial afterwards
since the victim node will only be seem by attackers.

3. Commence the aforementioned attack methods.


Resources required

An eclipse attack depends on having many IPs available to spam the network as nodes.
The more IPs are available, the quicker the attack si and the higher its success rate is. Tools
such as a large botnet would be very useful in this attack. For confidence, an attacker would
need IPs numbering into the thousands.


Countermeasures implemented

The Bitcoin network has since implemented some counter measures to prevent Eclipse attacks
in this style. One change was in reworking peer tables so to randomize selection, avoiding the
fresh IP bias. Another was to create feeler connections as to avoid filling up the Peer Table with
dead IPs, further reducing effectiveness of IP spam.

articles.title: What is RANSOMEWARE?
articles.description:
This word indicates a class of malware that makes the data of infected computers inaccessible and demands a ransom to be paid to restore them. In fact, in English the term "ransom" means redemption.
Technically they are cryptographic Trojan horses (or "Trojan horses", i.e. malware that hide their functioning inside another useful and harmless program. The user, by running or installing this latter program, also unconsciously activates the code of the hidden Trojan). These computer tricks have the sole purpose of extorting money, through a "file seizure", that is, encrypting all the data on the computer of the attacked user, effectively making the device unusable. Instead of the classic background, we will therefore see a warning appear that seems to come from the police or another security organization and proposes an offer that changing a password can unlock all the contents, but which requires you to pay a sum of money. The fee is generally requested in a virtual currency (cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin, the most used), which is usually not traceable.


How ransomware spreads

E-mail is the favorite channel of distribution for hackers. In particular, cybercriminals are implementing increasingly elaborate phishing campaigns to trick users into "forcing" them to download the ransom virus and install it on their computers. Like any other phishing campaign, malware self-replicates and spreads across the web, using the infected computer's email address book.



How ransomware works

Even if the result is the same - computer locked and unusable - the behavior of the ransom virus varies depending on the malware family that infects the computer. In the case of what is called "Police virus"), the ransomware blocks access to the computer system by displaying a false notice from the Postal Police or the FBI, asking for a sum - usually not too high - to unlock access to the computer. device. In the second case, that of crypto lockers at WannaCry, the user will still be able to access his computer, but the files (text documents, movies, music files, and even folders) will be encrypted and therefore unusable. Also in this second case, the payment of a ransom will be required to obtain the key to unlock the cryptographic algorithm.
Furthermore, users will have a certain amount of time (usually a week, sometimes even less) to pay the ransom: otherwise, the hackers will not provide the unlock key and the only solution will be to format the computer.


How can you defend yourself from these attacks?

Here are some practical tips to not easily run into this type of threat:

    • Make sure you are backing up your data and have a recovery plan in place in the event of a successful phishing attack;
    • Have up-to-date antivirus software and be sure to thoroughly scan any items downloaded directly from the Internet to ensure they are virus-free;
    • When using word processing programs, such as Microsoft Word, be sure not to enable macros, as macro languages ​​are built into documents. If it is possible to run applications when documents are open, the user can accidentally run the malware on the computer through the embedded code;
    • Make sure not to open suspicious attachments in emails, or to download unverified files from the Internet through dangerous vectors such as web links present in the body of some suspicious emails, or within banners, i.e. windows that automatically open suddenly during the browsing on websites, to induce the user to open unwanted pages created in some cases for malicious purposes.

articles.title: What is proof of work(PoW)
articles.description:
Proof of Work (PoW) describes a system that requires significant but achievable efforts to prevent the frivolous or malicious use of computing power, for example. Hal Finney later adapted this concept in 2004 with the idea of "reusable proof of work" with the SHA-256 hashing algorithm to protect digital money.
Following its introduction in 2009, Bitcoin was the first widespread use of Finney’s PoW idea (Finney also acquired the first Bitcoin transaction). Proof of Work underpins many other cryptocurrencies and provides a secure decentralized agreement.

Here's how proof-of-work works

Bitcoin is a blockchain, a ledger that contains the history of every Bitcoin transaction that has taken place. As the name suggests, this blockchain is made up of blocks. The latest transactions are saved in each block.

Proof of work is an important part of adding new blocks to the bitcoin blockchain. Miners choose the blocks they feed and the ecosystem members who do so. The network accepts a new block every time the miner generates a new proof of success, which happens approximately every 10 minutes.

Proof of work is hard to find, and the only way to be sure that working miners are producing bitcoins is to use expensive specialized computers. Bitcoin miners will profit if they guess the correct calculation. The more they charge, the more chance they have of earning bitcoins.


What kind of calculation do miners do?

In Bitcoin, miners emit a so-called "hash" that converts the input data into an arbitrary array of letters and numbers.
The goal of the miners is to create a hash that fits their "current Bitcoin target". They have to create a hash with many leading zeros. You are unlikely to get multiple zeros in a row. But miners around the world do trillions of these calculations per second, so it takes about 10 minutes on average.
Whoever reaches the goal, wins a lot of bitcoin cryptocurrencies first. Then the Bitcoin protocol creates a new value that the miners must code, and the miners start the race again to get proof of their winning work again.


Why is proof of work required?

The goal of Proof of Work is to prevent users from printing extra coins that they haven't earned or spent twice as much. If users could use their coins more than once, the coin would have little or no value.
With most digital currencies, this problem is easy to fix. The bank in charge of the system keeps track of how much money everyone has. When Alice sends $1 to Bob, the bank subtracts $1 from Alice and gives $1 to Bob.


What are the problems with proof of work?

There are at least some problems with proof of work:
High energy consumption: Given the evidence of the work, Bitcoin uses as much energy as Switzerland as a whole. And energy consumption is increasing as more and more miners turn to bitcoin hunters, even though some of them use renewable energy sources.


51% Attacks:

If a mining organization can accumulate 51% of Bitcoin’s mining hashrate, it can temporarily break the rules, throw twice as many coins, and block transactions.

Centralizing Mining: The proof of the work is to create a coin without one single entity in charge. In practice, however, the system is somewhat centralized, with only three mining groups controlling almost 50% of Bitcoin’s computing power. However, developers are trying to at least solve this problem.

articles.title: Ethereum plasma
articles.description:
Ethereum can only make 15 transactions per second on its 1st layer, and not only is this
inefficient, but it can also get pricy. Many solutions are being developed to increase the
scalability of Ethereum, one of which is Ethereum Plasma. This solution was once one of the
most dominant in the scaling narrative, however it has since taken a back seat. Despite this,
Plasma still has its place in the scaling wars.


What is Plasma?


Plasma works by allowing a series of alternative blockchains to be built parallel to Ethereum, with a security basis in the main Ethereum network.
These are called ‘sidechains’, or ‘child chains.’
 Sidechains are built with the goal of providing as much of the security of the main Ethereum network as possible, while improving on transaction processing metrics, and also usually maintaining the same functionality in smart contracts. In essence, a good plasma chain
should act as a regular blockchain, with the user only noticing they are not using Ethereum
through its greater efficiency and in making transfers between the sidechain and the main
network.
The main aspect of maintaining security in Plasma is in the way in which sidechains are
integrated into the main Ethereum network. The sidechain is based on a series of smart
contracts which define/link to it on the main network, and the sidechain will also submit hashes
of blocks to the network. It should be emphasized that it is only the hashes of plasma block that
are stored on the main chain, there is no need to store every transaction there as changes in
underlying transactions would change block hashes. This keeps most of the chain’s security
while storing minimal information on the main network, therefore reducing fees and congestion.



Implementations


Plasma has been implemented in a few major projects, with varying degrees of adoption. Most
surviving Plasma projects have integrated other scaling solutions as well in order to maximize
efficiency.

OMG

- Formerly OmiseGo, this was one of the first plasma projects to gain wide attention,
though it also began using Optimistic rollups beginning in May of 2021.

Polygon


- Formerly Matic, Polygon implements Plasma along with other scaling solutions such as
Rollups, Proof-of-stake, its own sidechains, and other more unique solutions.


Does Plasma work as a layer-2 solution?

After plasma was first proposed in 2017, it dominated the narrative on Ethereum scaling
for years. However, as layer 2 solutions have now been actually implemented on the network,
Plasma has taken a back seat. Though it still has its place, solutions originally marketed as
using Plasma have found it more efficient to integrate other layer-2 solutions as well. Most still
implement at least aspects of Plasma, though it may not always be the main player. Though
maybe not good for hardcore Plasma fans, these integration solutions have been highly
effective in achieving the original goals of Plasma on creating more efficient layer-2 Ethereum
networks.

articles.title: What is proof of stake (PoS)?
articles.description:
The voting power of a miner in the proof-of-work results from his computing power, as this determines the probability of block generation in the network and thus also his influence. The basic idea of ​​the Proof of Stake (PoS) is to decouple the voting power of a miner from his computing power, towards weighting based on the number of coins in his possession.


Here, the probability of a subscriber generating a block depends on its share in the network in terms of value, i.e. the share of its assets in the respective virtual currency in relation to the total assets. The computational effort and the associated resources resulting from the PoW are thus saved. Another advantage is the shorter block generation cycles. Studies show, however, that this approach, compared to PoW, is accompanied by other and sometimes serious problem areas with regard to the security of the blockchain.


The coins created as a reward during the block generation and the transaction fees retained are distributed randomly and periodically to the coin owners, with the probability of a participant being paid out based on the cumulative value of the coins they represent and the duration of the power of disposal over them. In contrast to the PoW, it is not the computing power but the assets that are used to protect against manipulation. An attacker must have more than half of the total assets to be able to lead a valid parallel chain with a sufficiently high probability.


WHAT IS PROOF OF AUTHORITY(PoA)

Proof of Authority is a mechanism with which a consensus is to be reached when validating and generating new blocks for a blockchain. It helps to select trustworthy participants in the blockchain who are then entrusted with these tasks. The selection depends on the reputation of the participants: the better the reputation of a participant, the more trustworthy they are.


Proof of Authority

Reputation rather than wealth is decisive
With the consensus mechanism Proof of Stake, those participants in a network have a particularly high probability of being selected for the validation of blocks that have many coins. The idea behind this is that participants with a high share in a network are less interested in damaging this network through manipulation. Proof of Authority (PoA) uses this basic idea but rejects the idea that high wealth equates to high trustworthiness. Instead, participants have to go through an application process if they want to be considered as validators for the blockchain.

Proof of Authority benefits


The hurdle of being recognized as a validator in a system that works with Proof of Authority is very high. Especially in comparison with other mechanisms in which z. If, for example, the available computing power alone decides a miner's chances, this becomes clear. A participant must be willing to reveal their real identity and submit to scrutiny. To a certain extent, you invest your good reputation and the disclosure of your identity in the system. In addition, with his reputation, he will later guarantee that the validations he has made are permissible and correct. Participants with fraudulent intentions have poor chances of success in the Proof of Authority, which is why the trustworthiness of such systems is often rated as particularly high.

articles.title: Game theory and cryptocurrencies
articles.description:
Game theory has underpinned the development of cryptocurrency and has been one of the reasons behind Bitcoin's success for over a decade, despite numerous attempts to disrupt the network.

What is the game theory?

Game theory is an applied mathematical method used to study human behavior through rational decision-making. The "game" is designed to be an interactive environment, so players tend to act rationally in response to the rules of the game or the influence of other players.

This concept was first developed in economics to study the behavior of businesses, markets, and consumers, but is now widely used in other areas of research. Thus, game theory models can be used as a tool to study the potential behavior of interactive agents and the potential consequences of their actions under predetermined circumstances. These models can also be applied to the broad study of politics, sociology, psychology, and philosophy.

Game theory and cryptocurrencies

When applied to cryptocurrencies, game theory models play an important role in designing a secure and insecure economic system, such as the Bitcoin system. The creation of Bitcoin as a fault-tolerant Byzantine system (BFT) is the result of a harmonious blend of cryptography and game theory.

The use of game theory in the context of cryptocurrencies is the concept of cryptocurrency, which is essentially the study of the economics of blockchain protocols and the potential implications of designing those protocols for participants' behavior. . ... He is also interested in the behavior of "external agents" who are not part of the ecosystem, but who can disrupt the network by trying to disrupt it from within.
That is the crypto-economy studies the behavior of network nodes based on the incentives offered by the protocol, taking into account the most rational and probable decisions.

Since the Bitcoin blockchain is designed as a distributed system, with many nodes spread over different locations, it must be based on the agreement of those nodes in terms of transaction and block validation. However, these nodes cannot trust each other. So how can such a system prevent malicious activity? How can a blockchain prevent disruption by dishonest nodes?

One of the most important features of the Bitcoin network that protects it from malicious activity is the well-functioning consensus algorithm. Apply cryptographic techniques that make the mining process more expensive and difficult, creating an extremely competitive operating environment. Therefore, the architecture of PoW-based cryptocurrencies encourages mining nodes to act honestly (so that they do not risk losing their invested resources). Instead, any malicious activity is quickly discouraged and punished. Dishonest mining nodes will likely lose a lot of money and get kicked off the network. Therefore, the most likely and rational decision for a miner to make is to act honestly and protect the blockchain.

CONCLUSION

A common application of game theory is to model and study how people behave and make decisions based on their rational minds. Therefore, game theory models should always be considered when designing distributed systems, for example, for cryptocurrencies.
Through a balanced combination of cryptography and game theory, the Proof of Work consensus algorithm was able to create the Bitcoin blockchain as a decentralized economic system that is highly resistant to attacks. The same is true for other cryptocurrencies, and game theory concepts apply to PoS blockchains as well. The main difference here lies in the way transactions are processed and the block is verified in the proof of participation blockchain.
However, keep in mind that the degree of security and resiliency of the blockchain depends on its protocol and directly depends on the number of participants in the network. Large distributed networks are more reliable than small ones.

articles.title: What is Mimblewimble?
articles.description:
Mimblewimble (abbreviated as MW) is a blockchain system that employs a revolutionary transaction architecture and storing approach. It's a novel Proof of Work blockchain technology that improves network scalability and anonymity. 
The Mimblewimble protocol was created in 2016 by a famous pseudonym named Tom Elvis Jedusor. Even though he was able to convey the essential themes, the first Mimblewimble book left some unsolved problems. As a result, Blockstream researcher Andrew Poelstra started to investigate and develop the original concept. Since then, several researchers and developers have been studying the capabilities of the MW protocol. Even while it is technically possible, some believe that implementing it on Bitcoin would be impossible.


How Mimblewimble Operates

The transaction structure of Mimblewimble is based on a protocol known as "Confidential Transactions." A similar method is used by other privacy coins like Monero. To put it another way, it all starts with a private transaction in which a sender's desired quantity of a certain token is encrypted using "blinding factors." Blinding factors are values chosen at random by the sender and must be chosen by the recipient. If the receiver selects a similar value, the transaction is considered authentic. In Mimblewimble, the sender must select blinding factors. This serves as proof of ownership for the recipient, allowing them to utilize the currency.


Features of Mimblewimble

One of the most important components of the Mimblewimble protocol is the Cut through feature. This is a function that authorizes blocks containing massive amounts of data to be compressed and much of that data to be removed without endangering the integrity of the blockchain.
They also use the cryptographic function Coinjoin, which allows several users' payments to be combined. This was done to create a single transaction and make it difficult to figure out which money was intended for which recipient. As a result, only those who are involved in the activity, and no one else, may have access to this data.

Pros


MimbleWimble's blockchain has three main benefits over the blockchains of other cryptocurrencies. These include:

  • Anonymity
    If the issuer or receiver's public addresses are unknown or unregistered, it is impossible
    to trace the path of operations and funds. As a result, the security of no user will be
    affected.


  •  Scalability
    Due to the small amount of space that transactions require within the blocks of the MW
    blockchain, the protocol structure of the MW blockchain is much more scalable than
    others, such as Bitcoin.


  • Fungibility
    Fungibility refers to a currency's ability to be exchanged for another unit without losing its
    value. Due to the lack of address registration on the MW blockchain, the source of the
    coins will stay unknown. As a result, they are unable to be described negatively.

Cons

It is a remarkable fact that anything remarkable will have some negatives. Here are the two most important ones:

  • Increase in Transaction throughput
    Systems that offer confidential transaction implementations have slower transaction
    speeds due to the amount of data involved.


  • Reliance on electronic signatures
    Mimblewimble is vulnerable to quantum computer attacks because it relies on
    authentication.


Conclusion

Mimblewimble is a substantial advancement in the protection of anonymity and secrecy, which is likely what most earlier coins were created for. Because it lacks traceability and a rigorous validation procedure, the Mimblewimble protocol paradigm is easier to implement than many other blockchain systems now available.
For several reasons, Grin and Beam picked the Mimblewimble protocol for their implementations. Addresses, transaction amounts, and a complete history of all transactions are all missing from both coins. It's unclear whether Mimblewimble will be able to achieve high levels of reliability and acceptance for the time being. Although it's an intriguing and exciting concept, it's still in its early stages. As a result, many use cases are being looked at, and Mimblewimble's future is yet unknown.

articles.title: What is liquidity?
articles.description:
The concept of liquidity is multifaceted and affects the price of bitcoin. One way to determine liquidity is that the asset can be converted into cash on demand. Another point of view is that liquidity is determined by the bid-ask spread, while an investment with a lower bid-ask spread has higher liquidity. Thus, liquidity means that there are no discounts or bonuses attached to the assets bought or sold, and it is easy to get in and out of the market.
The market usually becomes more competitive when more than one item is bought and sold. The possibility of charging a premium or receiving a discount is reduced. Typically, this type of asset is traded at a price close to the market price. The forex market is generally considered to be the most liquid market. According to the Bank for International Settlements (BIS), the average turnover in the foreign exchange market in April 2019 was about $ 6.6 trillion per day. On the other hand, real estate is a classic example of an illiquid asset. Buying and selling real estate often requires months of work, negotiation, filling out tedious forms, and paying large commissions.
Liquidity is needed for any traded asset, including Bitcoin cryptocurrency. Liquid markets are deeper and smoother, and an illiquid market can put traders in hard-to-leave positions.

What drives liquidity in crypto?

Open market

Money is widely considered to be the most liquid asset because it can be easily converted into other asset classes.
In the case of cryptocurrencies, an open market means that a digital asset can be legally traded on several exchanges.
Illiquid cryptocurrencies can lead to a lack of demand.
Imagine trying to create an "open market" for selling reusable socks. You may find niche buyers, but you won't be able to go to the bank and exchange those socks for cash.
Likewise, cryptocurrency creation requires adequate income and expenditure for cryptocurrency creation.

These are financial gateways that allow you to convert digital assets to cash and vice versa, e.g. fiat-to-currencies exchanges like liquid or cryptocurrency wallet providers.
As the industry grows, we may see more platforms that will allow people to integrate cryptocurrencies into their daily finances, such as South Korean stores that offer cryptocurrency top-ups or nearly 3,000 bitcoin ATMs found across the US.


Buyers and Sellers

Liquid markets rely on market makers willing to buy and sell assets. The increased trading activity ensures that sellers are selling competitively while buyers bids at a higher price, creating a relatively stable balance.
Illiquid markets tend to be volatile due to slippage. Slippage is the difference between the expected price and the price to be paid.
In illiquid markets, fewer market participants go to the other side of the trade, so there is more time between order placement and execution after a buyer or seller is found. During this period, the price of the asset may change, creating a gap between the price at which the order is placed and the price at which the order is requested.
When liquidity is required to buy or sell an asset without affecting the overall price, illiquidity refers to individual market orders that significantly affect the market price.

articles.title: Getting to know about assembly (WASM)
articles.description:
Four years ago, in March 2017, a new format intended to enable high-performance applications on the web appeared. This format was called WebAssembly, but you might also hear it being called by its abbreviation, which is WASM. Most people know it to be an open standard that allows the execution of binary code on the web, but that’s not all. There’s a whole lot to know about WASM, such as its history, its background, its uses, and its advantages, but first, let’s start with answering this question; what exactly is WebAssembly?


What is WebAssembly?

WebAssembly is a binary instruction format for a stacked-based virtual machine. To make things easy to understand, the first thing you should know about WASM is that it is a programming language. But what kind of programming language you might ask? It is generally a Low Level language that has a compact binary format that operates and provides languages with low-level memory models with a compilation to help them run on the web easily. The WebAssembly is a stack machine, and this is because it operates under ISA, which is a set of instructions that allow the loops, memory access, and even the arithmetic operations to be controlled.


History/Background of WASM

As you read earlier, WASM first appeared in March 2017, about 4 years ago, but the fact is that it was first announced in 2015 by demonstrating Unity’s Angry Bots in Firefox, Google Chrome, and Microsoft Edge. It was after this, in September 2017, that Safari 11 was released. Then months after that in February 2018, three public working drafts were published specifically for the Core Specification, JavaScript Interface, and WE API as well. It was designed by the World Wide Web Consortium and licensed by Apache License.


How Can WASM be Used?

By now, you already know what WebAssembly is, and you should already have a fair idea of how important it is. But what exactly can be WASM be used for? Here are some of its functions;

  • It can be used as a portable compilation target for programming language. That is what it was designed for.
  • It can also be used as a binary instruction format for a stack-based virtual machine.
  • It enables deployment on the web client and the server applications as well.
  • It offers a relatively close native performance on the web while maintaining compatibility with the standards at the same time.


Advantages of using WebAssembly

WebAssembly has a couple of advantages, and some of them are;


1. It is very safe
It is safe because it enforces the permissions and the security policies of the browser, preventing unwanted applications in the process. WebAssembly is a memory-safe environment that can be used even in JavaScript virtual machines. 

2.  It is highly efficient and smart
Get ready to embrace high speed with the WASM stack machine because it is created in such a way that it is encoded in an efficient binary format. It achieves this by using the common hardware found on many platforms.

3. It is Debuggable
WebAssembly is designed in a textual format that is debuggable and can be used to view modules.


Wrap Up

That’s it! The nitty-gritty of WebAssembly. When compared to JavaScript, significant improvement has been seen in most of the execution of the tasks. It doesn’t necessarily mean that WebAssembly is better than JavaScript in every single aspect, but it does show that WebAssembly is faster in the execution of most tasks when tested. The impact of WebAssembly in web development cannot be overestimated, but it doesn’t mean that it is going to replace JavaScript, especially when it comes to those applications that deal with APIs.

articles.title: Hash Collison
articles.description:
In computer science, a collision is a random match of hash values ​​that occurs when a hash algorithm produces the same hash value for given two regions.
One of the most common methods to prevent interception on digital communications by third parties is to use hashing algorithms.
The hashing process provides the level of security required to pass the message to the recipient. As a standard practice in computing, hashing is used for a variety of purposes, including data encryption, indexing, and compression.
Hashing and cryptography go hand in hand as both works on the principle of protecting data by converting it into a secure format. Although cryptography uses a process called encryption, hashing uses a hash function that includes a mathematical formula designed to evaluate one value against another.


What is hashing algorithm?


As you know, hashing algorithms are at the heart of most cryptocurrencies. In short, a hash algorithm is a mathematical function that converts an input string of any length to a fixed-length output string. The hash function always returns the same output for a given string. This way the files can be verified, for example, if the document returns a different hash on receipt, you know it has changed it. Also, it makes the blockchain unchanged like Bitcoin and many other currencies because changing a transaction or block results in a completely different hash. Because each block has a hash output of the previous block as input, the chain is broken and is not accepted by the system. This is what makes the blockchain secure.


So what is a hash collision? This word means that the hash output of two separate inputs will be returned. This would mean that someone could mess up a bitcoin file or even a transaction without their knowledge. Any hashing algorithm is considered disabled when a collision occurs.


Thus, if a hashing algorithm that is considered corrupt were used by cryptocurrencies, it could create a problem, as in theory, it would mean that previously mined blocks can now be changed and updated without recognizing the blockchain.


The hash output from previous transactions is the same, so the chain remains intact. Fortunately, most cryptocurrencies use SHA-256, the optimal hashing method. This algorithm has a much larger output size, which makes it much more secure than MD5 and SHA-1, for example.


Types of hash algorithms.
