Ideally, a good hash function should calculate quickly and be able to get the same hash value for two different inputs (collision). Programmers use different types of hashing algorithms depending on the level of security needed.


Although the MD5 hashing algorithm was one of the most popular hashing algorithms, today it is a compromised algorithm that easily creates collisions. Today, the Secure Hash Algorithm family of hash algorithms (SHA-2 and SHA-3) is considered the most secure.

Many programmers believe that the best approach is to use existing hashing algorithms so attackers cannot change the projected hash values.


IOTA


IOTA had developed a hashing algorithm called Curl. A team belonging to the MIT Media Lab came forward and demonstrated that with the same output hash, they were able to build multiple payments in the IOTA tangle. Before going public, they told the IOTA team and some changes to the hashing algorithm were made.


Since these algorithms are the basis of blockchain projects, it is crucial that these algorithms are reliable and that collisions can almost be impossible to make, as a blockchain application may be lost.

articles.title: What is Hashing?
articles.description:
Hashing is a process of codensing text into fixed cryptograpic output using a mathematical algorithm.

In other words, inputting any line of text in a hashing function will return a text string of a standardized size that is unique to the input.

The process is the basis for many aspects of cryptography and blockchain technology.



How does hashing work?


Hash functions take inputs of different lengths to return outputs of the same lengths. As
an example, we will run strings of text through the MD5 hashing function. Note that both output
strings are exactly 32 characters long, this maintains security, as it makes it impossible to guess
the underlying text length without the function. However, the hash outputs could be run through
a reverse function to retrieve the input text.

  • Input: The quick brown fox
  • MD5 Hash Output: 30f3c93e46436deb58ba70816a8ec124
  • Input: Jumps over the lazy dog
  • MD5 Hash Output: 3877f6a710f94c8055a6f9af7035672e

In a hash function, the output will always be entirely unique to the underlying text string.
Changing even one letter will change the output string of the function completely.

Input: The quick brown fax
MD5 Hash Output: d56ccce431580bc3b9c06ec6602b1e78
MD5 is just one cryptographic formula.
There are other major formulas such as SHA-256 which is used by Bitcoin, and Keccak-256 which is used by the Ethereum blockchain.
Other common formulas include SHA-2, SHA-3, and BLAKE3.


There are three important aspects to a good hashing function

  • No two inputs should generate the same output
  • The input value should not be guessable from the output
  • It should be difficult to predetermine an output from an input


Applications


Hashes have many applications in security, data structures, and data storage. These
uses stem from prime functions of either encrypting data or compressing data. Hashes serve
notable roles combining all of these functions in blockchain systems.
In a proof of work blockchain, Miners work with complex hashes in order to validate
transactions. Miners attempt to create a hash equal to a target hash by essentially guessing
numbers at high rates of speed.
Hashes are also used in the storage and data structure of blockchains. In order to keep
chain data in order, each block in a chain will contain a hash of the previous block called a
Merkle root. The Merkle root is a hash consisting of hashes of all the underlying transactions in
a block. It is useful for data and security as one change in any transaction would result in a
complete change of the Merkle root. The validation of the Merkle roots helps to maintain
blockchain immutability. Merkle roots also serve another purpose in allowing for the operation of
lighter blockchain nodes, as nodes may download only the merkle roots rather than the full
transaction data. The Merkle root is significantly smaller than the block it is based on, so much
so that this often results in data compression to sizes thousands of times smaller.

articles.title: How cryptocurrency mining malware spreads,  how to detect and prevent it
articles.description:
Cryptocurrency mining malware is virtually a subtle malware that farms the resources on computers, smartphones, and other internet-connected electronic devices to produce cash for the cybercriminals that manage it. This form of malware uses your resources to mine cryptocurrency on your device in a way that you are unaware of.
Crypto mining software, which secretly mines cryptocurrencies using a computer's resources, has been on the rise for the past year, and now hackers are aiming their target on gamers to do their malicious deeds. Hackers are hiding malware from famous games like NBA 2K19 and Pro Evolution Soccer 2018 to infect devices, according to a study made by the antivirus company Avast. Crackonosh, the virus in question, appears to be of Czech origin, and the researchers claim that the hackers have made over $2 million so far through infecting devices.
Crowdsourcing crypto mining activities is a common application of crypto-mining malware. During the past year, as the Cryptocurrency industry has grown, the number of cases of this malware has greatly increased. 


How It Spreads


When it comes to the transmission of crypto mining malware, it should be noted that it behaves similarly to virtually any other computer infection. As you might expect, the most common approach to get one of these is to download it on the internet by visiting any of the unsecured websites. When it comes to prevention, it's safe to say that it's very much the same as you're used to. When we say this, we imply that you should only access and download from secure websites and that you should keep your anti-virus software up to date.


How to Detect It


Now let's go through how to detect crypto-mining malware on your computer. First, your CPU will become substantially slower over time, which is the first symptom you may notice. Mining, as you might expect, necessitates a great deal of speed and endurance. As a result, if you have a virus that has attached itself to your system, you might expect your system to become significantly slower than it is. It can even become ineffective in some circumstances. Furthermore, it may do further damage to your hardware from within.

Another sign that something went wrong is if your computer starts overheating from time to time. Naturally, you should look into other possibilities for why this is happening. If there isn't anything else, you should consider scanning your machine for the miner virus. The two components that will end up suffering the most, as you might expect, are the RAM and the CPU. However, this implies that the virus will not assault your computer's processor. Regardless, you can be certain that it will have an impact on the performance of your system.


How To Prevent Cryptocurrency Mining Malware


While attackers employ a variety of sophisticated strategies to conceal their actions, they first gain a foothold by targeting unpatched and vulnerable systems. Maintain your systems' security by keeping them up to date and using trusted security software. Most ad-blockers will help deter crypto-mining malware programs from executing on end users' devices.

At the enterprise level, it is advised that organizations ban URL/IPs of sites infected with crypto-mining malware scripts and domains of crypto-mining pools. There are a lot of domains out there, and they're only going to get bigger, so limiting the big pools is a good idea. The miners will not mine if they are unable to communicate with these servers. Crypto mining malware attackers, on the other hand, are among the most cunning of cybercriminals. To overcome them, security personnel must be equally as smart.

articles.title: What is End-to-end encryption (E2EE)?
articles.description:
End-to-end encryption ensures secure communication between two partners. The two communication partners carry out the encryption and decryption of the transmitted information directly. Other stations involved in the transmission cannot access the information.

The English term for end-to-end encryption is end-to-end encryption or E2EE for short. The end-to-end encryption enables the secure exchange of information between two communication partners. All transmitted information is encrypted by the sender and only decrypted again at the recipient. The data is only available in encrypted form over the entire transmission path. Third parties such as intermediate stations or service providers cannot access the content. Only control information is available to them that enables the forwarding or routing of the encrypted information.

Various cryptographic methods such as symmetrical or asymmetrical encryption with public and private keys are used for encryption. End-to-end encryption reliably prevents messages from being intercepted. The counterpart is the so-called point-to-point encryption. With this method, the information is only encrypted on sections of a transmission link. At intermediate stations, they are always available unencrypted in plain text and can be viewed by third parties.

How end-to-end encryption works


As a rule, end-to-end encryption uses symmetrical or asymmetrical encryption methods. With symmetrical procedures, the two communication partners have a secret key with which they encrypt and decrypt the data. If the secret key is in the possession of an unauthorized person, he can also encrypt and decrypt all data. In order for two communication partners to be able to exchange end-to-end encrypted data using the symmetrical process, they must have agreed and exchanged the secret key beforehand.
Asymmetric encryption uses public and private keys. The public key of a communication partner A is accessible to everyone. However, data encrypted with a public key can only be decrypted again with the associated private key. The private key is only known to communication partner A. This procedure is also called Public Key Encryption. It offers the advantage that the secret keys do not have to be exchanged before communication and that private keys always remain local with a communication partner. With this method, it is to be avoided that a wrong public key can be slipped under. This is provided by the public key infrastructure (PKI), certification authorities ( CA), and digital certificates.

The different areas of application of end-to-end encryption on the Internet


End-to-end encryption is used in various areas of Internet communication. Common chat applications such as WhatsApp, Apple iMessage, Telegram or Threema use E2EE. OpenPGP and S/MIME are common methods for end-to-end encryption in e-mail traffic. In order to exchange encrypted e-mails, the e-mail clients on the end devices involved must support the encryption method used.
The transmission of data from Internet pages between a server and a client can be secured with HTTPS (Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure). HTTPS ensures end-to-end encrypted connections between the web server and the web browser. SSL/TLS (Secure Sockets Layer / Transport Layer Security) is used for encryption, which is placed between HTTP and the transport protocol TCP.

articles.title: How does the blockchain work?
articles.description:
Until some time ago it was necessary a third party that the two parties trusted to guarantee the authenticity of the transactions (bank, auditor, notary, or Paypal) and that had a record or seal of veracity. Now, with the blockchain, this problem and double-spending disappear by combining P2P peer-to-peer technology with virtual currency and thus creating a new form of digital communication.

Likewise, the transactions included in the blocks are created by the members of the system. These are registered and transmitted to all nodes on the network. Thus, all members have the transaction information updated in real-time.


Transactions are made from so-called  “wallets” or electronic purses. Wallets are encrypted files that work in a similar way to a bank account, they have two keys: public and private.

The public key is an alphanumeric string between 26 and 35 characters, it is the Bitcoin address and it acts as the account number. In this way, for someone to send you bitcoins, you must first give them the public key and then receive the virtual currencies.

Meanwhile, the private key is used to authorize operations from your wallet. This process is what is known as asymmetric cryptography.


As new transactions are constantly flowing through the network, they will be added to a “ pool” (similar to a cooperative) of unverified transactions. This is where the figure of the so-called “miners” appears, who is in charge of choosing the transactions of these pools to create a new block of confirmed transactions.

The miners are dedicated to verifying the transactions that are happening at the moment and they fulfill two important functions: To create new bitcoins for each block that is mined and to ensure that the transactions are real and legitimate.

Mining pools are sets of miners who work together to solve a block and divide the rewards awarded.

Thanks to the use of the blockchain that is synchronized between the nodes, the irreversibility of the transactions are achieved, which allows nobody to make fraud to benefit, modifying the account book to divert the bitcoins from one place to another without others knowing.


This ledger is safe because the linked blocks have a “hash” (encoded) pointer that links to the previous block; Furthermore, all information is public. This means that although it protects the privacy of its users, it does allow control of the traceability of those transactions.
It should be noted that each block is a part of the chain with the following elements:


  • An alphanumeric code that links to the previous block.
  • A package of transactions.
  • Another alphanumeric code that will link to the back block.


When is Blockchain Used

As a distributed technology in which every node on the network stores an exact copy of the chain, blockchain guarantees the availability of information at any time. If an attacker wants to eliminate him, he must kill all nodes in the network, since for the availability of information it is enough for at least one to be operational.
Thus, blockchain technology allows you to store information that cannot be lost, changed, or deleted.

articles.title: Hybrid PoW/PoS consensus explained
articles.description:
The blockchain consensus mechanism is used to ensure agreement between participants about the current state of the blockchain. The consensus mechanism determines who can add new blocks of transactions, and one of its main goals is to ensure that the chain is not overwritten.

The purpose of hybrid proof-of-work and proof-of-stake systems is to capture the advantages of the respective approaches and thus compensate for their corresponding disadvantages. Decline is one of the few cryptocurrencies that uses PoW and PoS in an identifiable manner and is combined with a feature-rich or hybrid consensus mechanism.


Masternode coins are also a bit hybrid because they have a recognizable proof of work component that performs a similar function to Bitcoin and an additional function for special nodes. These nodes usually require a certain amount of currency as collateral to prove they can be trusted to act in the best interests of the network, which is similar to the reason for proving participation. Dash is the original Masternode currency and this model is called Proof of Service. This article focuses on hybrids that have a Stake Proof component and does not cover a set of parts that mimic masternodes or Proof of Service.


The Decred PoW component works the same as other PoW based projects and uses the Blake-256 hash function. The PoS Decred component and how it is woven into the chain is quite unique and deserves a more detailed explanation.


To participate in the Stake Decred Proof, cardholders must block their DCRs for the purchase of “tickets”. The price of one ticket is set by a mechanism similar to the market, in which the system indicates a certain number of live tickets (40,960) - if the target amount is exceeded, the price rises, because worse, it goes down. When someone buys a ticket, the RCD they are using will be blocked (meaning they cannot issue it) until their ticket is mistakenly called to vote or it expires in about 142 days. This leads to opportunity costs for PoS, which are designed to ensure that PoS voters play an important role in the game and act in the best interests of the network.


PoS contributors (also known as voters or stakeholders) have three different roles to play: blocking the vote, voting on changes to the consensus rules, and voting on project-level governance using the Politeia proposal system. The first, the "blocking vote," is how PoS voters are directly involved in maintaining consensus.


Hybrid PoW / PoS design dramatically increases the cost of network attacks because there are two different systems that an attacker must avoid. In particular, the PoS component is configured in such a way that tickets can be bought very slowly. You can buy a limited number of tickets in each block/slot and buying the maximum number increases the price significantly. In addition, after purchasing these tickets, the funds used for the purchase are blocked for a certain period, so that the attacker is exposed to the devaluation of his blocked coins due to the attack.


If randomly selected stakeholders are required to vote for each block, the blockchain must be distributed among all participants during operation, which increases the security of the network. Decred's hybrid system is designed to empower stakeholders of PoW miners.

articles.title: What is block height?
articles.description:
The block height of a given block is defined as the number of blocks that precede it in the blockchain. Blockchain is an encrypted database that writes a log of sequential transactions in data structures called blocks. Blockchains are used as the underlying technology for cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin.

The block height can be related to the position of the transaction executed at the last position in the blockchain, or it can be related to the current length or size of the blockchain. The block height graph shows how new blocks are constantly being discovered in the blockchain over time at different levels of mining difficulty.

Understanding Block height


Blockchain is a series of sequential blocks, hence the name blockchain. These blocks are essentially blocks of data used to store information about transactions from the network. Each block contains a secure and public record of transactions that occurred or were verified in the interval between the previous block and the block in question.

The first block in the blockchain is called the genesis block. It has zero block height because there are no blocks in the previous blockchain. The total height of a chain of blocks is considered to be the height of the most recent block or the tallest block in the chain.

Block Explorer


The Block Explorer offers everyone the opportunity to track transactions online on a blockchain such as Bitcoin.
A block explorer is a tool that has been providing detailed analysis of a blockchain network since its first day on the Genesis block. We can say that a block explorer acts as a search engine and browser where users can find information about individual blocks, public addresses, and transactions associated with a particular cryptocurrency.
Some block explorers also provide real-time statistics and market charts, as well as data on mining pools, pending transactions, network hash rate, rich list, block validators, orphan blocks, hard forks, and much more.
In terms of pending transactions, block explorers can be useful for users waiting for block confirmations. For example, many exchanges provide their users with the transaction ID of their deposit or withdrawal request so that they can follow the development of their funds in real-time.

Depending on the type of blockchain, block explorers can also serve as a general information center. For example, thousands of ERC-20 tokens are running on the Ethereum blockchain, and users can find data about them by checking their smart contracts on Etherscan or any other Ethereum block explorer.
Block explorers are essential for monitoring the current state of a cryptocurrency network. When it comes to Binance Chain, users can see the current status for BNB in ​​the Binance Chain Explorer, including coin incineration transactions and current total.

Although we can have multiple block explorers on a single website, each explorer is associated with a specific blockchain. Still, there can be more than one block explorer for the same blockchain (different organizations offering a similar service). In addition to block explorers, some companies also offer crypto wallet services. That being said, many websites offer an API for developers to use the blockchain data in other ways.

Block weight


Block weight is a new concept introduced in Segwit and is charged per transaction. Each transaction has a "weight", which is defined as follows:

(tx size with witness data stripped) * 3 + (tx size)

tx= transaction + witness data

Non-Segwit transactions have zero token data, so the weight of a transaction without Segwit is exactly four times the size. Segwit transactions have witness data, so their weight is less than 4 times. Note. Segwit transactions are sent to legacy nodes without token data, so this formula always results in blocks reported to legacy nodes that are less than or equal to 1,000,000 bytes.

Typically, each byte in a transaction counts as a 4-byte block weight. However, if a byte is part of the SegWit Bitcoin Witness Zone, it receives a discount and only counts as a 1-byte block weight.

Suppose you previously received some BTC to Bitcoin address SegWit A and some BTC to old address B. Now imagine a transaction that sends these two amounts to an address C. Data that has nothing to do with transaction entries is always data, no witnesses are counted as 4 bytes/byte. In particular, the C address is irrelevant and could be SegWit, non-SegWit, or whatever. Witness data relating to address A are placed in the SegWit witness area and counted as 1 byte/byte. The evidence for address B is not SegWit specific and therefore counts as 4 bytes per byte.

Block depth


The index of the position of the block in the blockchain relative to the last (most recently added) block. A block that is five blocks before the last block has a block depth of 5.

Transaction confirmation is a common concept in Bitcoin. Some online stores that accept Bitcoin may require one or more transaction confirmations before they can deliver their product or service. Every transaction exists in a block of the blockchain. The blocks behind it are older and the blocks in front of it are newer. The position of the block relative to the top of the blockchain is called block depth. The last block added is 1 dept, the block behind it is 2 dept, and so on.


Hash rate


The hash rate is also called the mining rate and represents the computational power and mining speed when mining virtual currencies such as Bitcoin.
It is expressed in units of "hash / s" and indicates how many times a second is calculated. Therefore, a high hash rate indicates that the processing power is strong and a low hash rate indicates that the processing power is weak.
The higher the hash rate, the more efficient extraction is possible.

Hash rate is an important value in assessing the power of a blockchain network, more precisely its security. The more honest miners use machines to discover the next block, the higher the hash rate and the harder it becomes for malicious agents to break the network.

For example, a 51% attack occurs when a single person or group of attackers buys or rents enough mining equipment to control more than 50% of a blockchain's hash rate. Because blockchains are reliable and adhere to a rule known as the "longest chain rule", a person or group that controls much of the hash rate could, in theory, block or reorder transactions and even cancel payments. This would create duplicate spending issues, which in turn would completely undermine the integrity of the core blockchain.

Therefore, a decrease in hash rate means a 51% reduction in the cost of an attack, which makes the network more vulnerable.

articles.title: What is a time-jacking attack?
articles.description:
A time-jacking attack is a hypothetical vulnerability in the Bitcoin network that was hotly debated in the early days of cryptocurrency. It's a bug that takes advantage of the way Bitcoin handles timestamps. When connecting to a Bitcoin node, an attacker can create or broadcast a bogus timestamp of a transaction, which allows the attacker to manipulate the node's network time and persuade it into adopting an alternative Blockchain.
This indicates that the attacker could take advantage of it to make a network double spend. Time-jacking is a terrifying prospect. In reality, a group of malevolent miners can time jack a group of miners, removing them from the system while increasing their hash rate percentage.

How Time-Jacking Attack Spreads


A timestamp is used in the creation of Bitcoins, and these are essential to the circulation of Bitcoin. The difficulty of mining Bitcoin is precisely proportional to these timestamps, and the Bitcoin system adjusts the network difficulty automatically based on the timestamps of how long it took to process and mine the previous block.
Bitcoin nodes contain an internal clock that generates these timestamps and synchronizes the network time to ensure that it is consistent with other nodes. The Blockchain system is built on the foundation of timestamps. If you look at your operating node, you'll notice that it's currently using the time base on your device. If these timestamps vary by more than 60 minutes from those of other nodes, the node is considered untrustworthy and is removed from the Blockchain. It's deemed to be operating another chain until that time is accurate and synced up.
This 60-minute wiggle room in the system leads to time jacking. By connecting as many peers and providing erroneous timestamps using a modified system time on their machines, these attackers could accelerate or even slow down the node's time. Attacking the network's average time could result in transmitting multiple expenditures.
 

How Time-Jacking Attacks Works


Suppose that an attacker wishes to assault a certain target node. They use a simple method to launch a time jacking attack. They begin by launching a Sybil attack against the bitcoin network. An attacker can use a Sybil attack to gain control of numerous nodes in a network by creating thousands of false nodes and connecting them to the network. The attacker manipulates the timestamps of the nodes so that the target node is 70 minutes behind the clock while all other nodes are 70 minutes ahead. The target node and the rest of the network are separated by 140 minutes as a result of this.
Now, the attacker mines a new block with a timestamp that is 190 minutes ahead of actual time, utilizing their hash rate power. When this new block is sent, the target node rejects it right away because it is not within the 120-minute restriction, according to them.
As a result, the attacker has succeeded in isolating the target node from the rest of the network. While everyone else is working on their chain, the target node begins working on its own. The attacker can now mine the target node for more free blocks and indulge in double-spending. They can even keep it going indefinitely if they keep tweaking the time jack.

Measures Imposed to Curb Out Time-Jacking Attacks


A time jacking attack is a one-time occurrence that will have a little long-term impact on Bitcoin. The operators of the genuine chain would have already detected and begun rejecting these new blocks as soon as the attack was completed. Anyone who accepts Bitcoin, including merchants, should be aware of the situation.
This is another issue that I would classify alongside quantum computing. It isn't a major issue, and it would be resolved rather quickly anyway. It necessitates a share of the network's processing capacity, so if such an attack occurred, ethical hackers might band together and temporarily increase their computing power to counter the attack.

articles.title: Leased proof of stake consensus explained
articles.description:
LPoS is an enhanced version of Proof-of-Stake. In a regular Proof-of-Stake system, each node that holds a certain amount of cryptocurrency is eligible to add the next block to the blockchain but in the LPoS system, on the Waves Platform, users can lease their balance to full nodes. With LPoS, the user will have the ability to Lease WAVES from the wallet to different contractors which can pay a percentage as a reward. The larger the amount that is leased to a full node, the higher the chances of that full node being selected to produce the next block. If that full node is selected to produce the next block, the leaser will then receive a percentage of the transaction fee that is collected by the full node. In a Leased Proof-of-Stake environment, users can choose between running a full node or leasing their stake to a full node with receiving rewards. This system allows anyone to participate in the Waves network maintenance. Users can lease their waves through leasing on any computer or mobile device that has an internet browser since Waves provides a lite client solution that does not require Miners, that are leasing their balance to store the whole Blockchain or to have the wallet running.

  • LPoS functionality
  • Balance Leasing
  • LPoS allows users to passively profit by renting coins from their wallets or other cold chambers for miners.


Fixed Tokens


LPoS mining does not send any signals to the network. The panels are fixed and rented. Lease signs get stuck in tenant accounts; therefore, they cannot be exchanged or transferred unless the landlord terminates the lease.


Decentralized


Most blockchains encourage users to join the mining pool by creating a centralized system. In LPoS, on the other hand, prizes are distributed linearly based on the bet amount; hence no mining pool is required. In addition, the lease follows a P2P protocol to ensure that no third parties are involved.


Transaction Fee Rewards


LPoS miners receive transaction fees as block rewards, as opposed to block rewards provided on most blockchains.

The advantages of a leased proof-of-stake

Validate with Less Stake

In a PoS network, validators are selected based on their share. This may call into question the correctness of a system in which some nodes are reselected. LPoS allows you to increase your chances of being selected by accepting rentals from other users.


Earn with Fewers Tokens


LPoS allows small tokens holders to make money by renting limited tokens to full node holders. Token holders receive a percentage of the profits that the entire node earns.


Control Of Funds


The rental tokens are blocked in the leased portfolio. They cannot be exchanged or transferred. While the tenant cannot spend the blocked funds, they can terminate the lease and make the rental money available for spending.


Less Energy Consumption


Leasing business can be activated over the phone. A handful of nodes can now perform the process that requires many high-powered computing nodes, with the help of phone users.


Higher Processing Speed


LPoS-based systems are fast and efficient because multiple nodes are involved in validating a transaction simultaneously. LPoS is a great alternative to Bitcoin PoW, which makes 4.6 transactions per second.

articles.title: What is a sybil attack?
articles.description:
A Sybil attack is a type of online security threat in which a single person attempts to seize control of a network by generating many accounts or nodes. It's as straightforward as having a single person creating several social media accounts. It is a kind of attack in which the attacker has control of a huge number of validators, and so has a formidable level of power over the network. The attacker subverts a network service's status system by generating a considerable number of pseudonymous identities and using them to wield a comparatively higher power.
The term was coined in 2002 by Brian Zill during a Microsoft Research Campaign and was named after the subject of the book titled "Sybil," a case study of a lady who was diagnosed with a dissociative identity disorder.
A typical example is seen in the world of cryptocurrencies in a scenario when someone carries out numerous nodes on a blockchain network.

Problems Associated with Sybil Attacks

Sybil attacks cause a series of problems with Blockchain technologies. First, if the attackers generate enough false identities, they may be able to out-vote the network's valid nodes. They can then abstain to receive or report blocks, virtually preventing additional users from linking to the network. A 51% attack can then be carried out in extremely large-scale Sybil attacks if the attackers manage to oversee the majority of the network processing power or hash rate. They may also alter the order of transactions and prevent transactions from being confirmed in such instances. They may even go back and reverse transactions they did while in control, emanating to double-spending.


The Mechanism of Sybil Attacks

The mechanisms of the attack follow a series of steps. The attackers' first objective is to bring down a network by ascertaining a large number of false identities. However, these identities appear to be autonomous users, but they are all controlled by the same entity. As a result, the attacker has tremendous voting power and has the potential to bring the network down or deteriorate it.
In most scenarios, Sybil attacks are usually misunderstood with Eclipse attacks. Meanwhile, false identities do not seek to completely deceive the network; instead, they sequester specific nodes by taking over all of their P2P connections. The attack might present a fictitious network state to selected elements by isolating them. In essence, Eclipse attacks only harm a segment of a network, whereas Sybil attacks tend to compromise the entire network.


Strategies Deployed in Preventing Sybil Attacks on Blockchains

Many scientists have spent a lot of time and exertion over the recent years attempting to figure out how to scrutinize and prevent Sybil attacks, with different lengths of success. Meanwhile, for the time being, there is no certain solution. Many blockchains, on the other hand, have employed some basic methods to prevent Sybil Attacks. To guard against Sybil attacks, the majority of them utilize various consensus algorithms such as Proof of Work and Proof of Stake. Meanwhile, these consensus algorithms don't ward off Sybil attacks; instead, they make it incredibly difficult for an attacker to carry it out successfully.
For instance, the generation of new blocks in Bitcoin's blockchain follows a set of regulations. One of the prerequisites is that the ability to construct a block must be proportional to the Proof of Work mechanism's overall processing power. That implies you must own the computing power required to form a new block, making it extremely difficult and costly for an attacker to do so.
Another thing to note is that most miners have a decisive intention to continue mining legally rather than undertaking a Sybil attack because Bitcoin mining is so overwhelming. The Proof of Stake model is presumed to function effectively because the amount of capital an attacker can stake is restricted, even if the initial cost of an attack is not directly plausible. By undertaking a Sybil attack, the attacker deteriorates public trust and value in the underlying protocol, thereby diminishing or erasing any profit from the attack.

articles.title: What is a selfish mining attack?
articles.description:
The selfish mining attack is an attack in which hostile nodes deviate from the conventional pattern by not immediately publishing newly generated blocks. It is one of the most popular attacks on the blockchain consensus mechanism.
This malevolent activity can result in those nodes receiving a disproportionate percentage of the rewards, especially if they have a lot of processing power. This exploit occurs when a bitcoin miner chooses to keep a legitimate block, they successfully mined hidden rather than broadcasting it to the network.
It depicts a malicious attempt to undermine the integrity of the blockchain network. The selfish miner continues to mine the following block after withholding their successfully mined block from the group, resulting in the selfish miner demonstrating more proof-of-work than the other miners in the mining pool. This lets the selfish miner collect block rewards while the rest of the network embraces the block solutions.
A selfish miner will keep their private chain and occasionally publicize it to receive higher rewards than they would otherwise receive based on their real contributions to the mining pool. During the mining process, however, numerous participants in a mining pool can indulge in selfish mining activity.

How Selfish Mining Attacks Works


Most popular cryptocurrencies, such as Bitcoin and Ethereum, have core security guarantees that an attacker must have more computer power than the rest of the network combined to successfully intervene with their network and block and revert transactions. The rationale for this is that these networks create a blockchain of their transaction history, with a randomized node putting a new block on top of an existing block every 10 minutes.
To revert a transaction, an attacker would need to make a transaction and then divide the blockchain one block behind the block in which the deal was included. From then, the attacker would be in a computational contest against all other miners as he tries to keep up.
The approach is summarized as follows: rather than operating as a normal miner and publishing blocks to the network as soon as they are discovered, the attacker selectively publishes blocks, sometimes at his own expense, but more often than not, releasing numerous blocks at once, forcing the rest of the network to ignore blocks and lose money.
In the short term, this reduces the attacker's revenue, but it also reduces everyone else's revenue, thus neutral nodes now have an incentive to join the attacker's coalition to improve their revenue. The attacker's coalition would eventually grow, potentially giving the attacker complete control over the network.
The attacker's precise technique is to keep a record of its own "private chain," which is distinct from the "public chain" used by the rest of the network. Both the private and public chains start the same way. The attacker mines on the private chain at all times and keeps any blocks he discovers secret. Meanwhile, the attacker's strategy specifies when he or she should disclose the blocks.


Solutions to Selfish Mining Attacks


To mitigate selfish mining attacks on blockchain networks, two viable methods have been presented. When a fork occurs, the first step is to assign miners to different branches of the blockchain at random, and the second is to set threshold restrictions for mining pools on the network to prevent selfish miners from getting a large advantage over other miners
Another option is to discriminate against a block based on the timestamp it was published. For instance, if a miner releases a large number of blocks all at once, the rest of the network will weigh their validity against the tags they encrypted and the one that was sent to the network.

articles.title: Merkle trees and merkle roots explained
articles.description:
Merkle trees and Merkle roots are cryptographic concepts that are essential to the
function of blockchains like Bitcoin and Ethereum. Named after the computer scientist who
patented the idea Ralph Merkle, who proposed them in a 1987 paper titled ‘A Digital Signature
Based on a Conventional Encryption Function.’ Merkle trees and roots enable blockchain data
to be encoded quickly and securely.


What are Merkle trees and Merkle roots?


Applied to a blockchain, a Merkle root is a cryptographic signature of all transactions in a

block. It is the end product of a Merkle tree, which itself is generated by repeatedly hashing

together pairs of transaction hashes until there is only one. The structure of the Merkle tree can

be thought of as mirroring an actual tree, with the initial hashes being the ‘leaves’, the

intermediate hashes being the ‘branches’, and the overarching hash being the Merkle root.


Example of a Merkle tree structure


A full Merkle tree is created by the following steps:


1. Consider a block that consists of 8 transactions:,Ta, Tb, Tc, Td, Te, Tf, Tg, Th
2. The transaction data is turned into hashes: Ha, Hb, Hc, Hd, He, Hf, Hg, Hh
3. Hashes are then paired together into new hashes: Hab, Hcd, Hef, Hgh
4. And again: Habcd,Hefgh
5. The last hash is the Merkle root: Habcdefgh


The full Merkle tree looks like this:


Habcdefgh
Habcd, Hefgh
Hab, Hcd, Hef, Hgh
Ha, Hb, Hc, Hd, He, Hf, Hg, Hh
Ta , Tb, Tc, Td, Te, Tf, Tg, Th


In practice, Merkle trees in a blockchain are far larger but follow the same structure.


Benefits of Merkle roots in blockchains


Merkle roots protect the integrity of blockchains by allowing easy verification of
transaction data.
If any part of any of the transactions in the underlying tree were to change, the
entire hash of the Merkle root would change.
Each block number is tied to a Merkle root of its transactions, so by looking at Merkle roots, nodes can stay in sync on the correct block data, and ignore manipulated block data.
It is far more efficient computationally and for data storageto validate this data by looking at a Merkle root rather than looking at every single transaction for possible changes.

In practice, blockchains will usually have ‘full nodes’ that consist of the full data on every
transaction, and ‘light nodes’ that only hold the Merkle roots of every block. This allows for much more practicality, as the entire bitcoin chain is over 330 gigabytes at the time of writing.
The merkle root of a block is only 80 bytes on average, and the datasize of most blocks is
approximately 1,000 times bigger than this.
Imagine having to download all of this data just to directly make a transaction on chain.
Light nodes that use Merkle roots allow for scalability that would be impractical otherwise.

articles.title: Private, public, and consortium blockchains - what's the difference? public blockchain
articles.description:
If you have recently used cryptocurrency, you may have interacted with a public blockchain. The vast majority of distribution registers today. We call them public because anyone can see current transactions, and membership is simple to download the necessary software.
We often use the term permissionless alongside the public. No custodian can interfere with participation and anyone can use a consent mechanism (for example, by exploitation or stake). Because anyone can participate and be rewarded for their role in building consensus, we would expect to see an extremely decentralized topology in a network built around a public chain.
Likewise, we expect a public blockchain to be more censorship-resistant than a private (or semi-private) blockchain. Since anyone can gain access to the network, the protocol must include certain mechanisms to prevent attackers from gaining anonymous gain.
However, the performance tradeoff comes from the approach to securing public channels. Many face barriers to scaling and the bottom line is relatively small. In addition, making changes to the network without sharing is challenging because everyone involved rarely agrees with the proposed changes.


Private Blockchain


Unlike the public blockchain, which does not require permissions, the private blockchain sets rules about who can see and write the chain (this is a permissioned environment). They are not decentralized systems as there is a clear hierarchy of controls. They are distributed by the fact that many nodes always keep a copy of the chain on their computers.


Private chains are best suited for corporate environments where an organization tries to take advantage of the properties of the blockchain without sharing its network from the outside.


Proof of work is wasted but has been found necessary in an open environment for the security model. In a private blockchain, however, the PoW threats are not harmful - the identity of each participant is known and practically managed.


Consortium or Federated Blockchain


The consortium's blockchain is halfway between public and private chains and combines elements of both. The biggest difference from all systems can be seen at the consensus level. Instead of an open system in which anyone can validate blocks or a closed system in which a unit appoints block manufacturers, a handful of equally powerful parties act as collectors in the consortium chain.


A blockchain consortium would be very useful in an environment where many organizations are operating in the same industry and need a common base for transactions or information transfer. Joining such a consortium can be beneficial for a company as it allows it to share information about its industry with other stakeholders.


Which is the best?


In principle, public, private and consortium blockchains do not contradict each other: They are different technologies:


  • Well-designed public chains tend to resist censorship at the expense of speed and efficiency. These are best suited for greater security guarantees in transaction settlements (or smart contracts).


  • A private chain can prioritize the speed of the system because it doesn't have to worry as much about the major points of failure as it does with the public blockchain. They are ideally used in situations where a person or organization needs to be held accountable and information needs to be kept confidential.


  • Consortium chains reduce some of the counterparty risks associated with the private chain (by eliminating centralized control), while fewer nodes usually allow them to perform much more efficiently than the public chain. Consortia can turn to organizations looking to facilitate communication.

articles.title: What is a decentralized exchange (DEX)?
articles.description:
Decentralized exchanges (DApps) are self-contained decentralized programs that allow cryptocurrency buyers and sellers to trade without handing over control of their cash to a third party. This infrastructure is distinct from centralized exchanges, which require customers to hand over their crypto assets to the exchange. DEXs were created to remove the requirement for any authority to oversee and authorize trades performed within a certain exchange. DEXs run automated order books and trades with the use of smart contracts. As a result, they are genuinely peer-to-peer.


How A Decentralized Exchange Works


In some aspects, DEXs are similar to their centralized counterparts, but they are vastly different in others. To begin, consumers should be aware that there are several distinct types of decentralized exchanges available. An on-chain order book, an off-chain order book, or an automated market maker approach are some of the options.
Every transaction in an on-chain order book is recorded on a blockchain. It also necessitates the use of miners to verify each transaction. Off-chain order books, unlike on-chain order books, keep records of transactions in a centralized entity. To manage these order books, they use relayers. Order books are not necessary with automated market makers. Instead, they use smart contracts to create liquidity pools that execute trades automatically based on preset parameters.


Pros of DEXs

Decentralized exchanges provide benefits in terms of digital asset custody, diversification, trading fees, and investor privacy. Let's have a look at them in more detail below:

  • Custody

Because DEXs are non-custodial, traders do not have to give up control of their private keys to transact. Instead, DEXs connect with externally owned wallets, and trades execute themselves using smart contracts.

  • Diversity

Many altcoins are only available through DEXs, which allow for P2P transactions without requiring large trading volumes. This expands the number of people who can invest in digital assets and improves financial inclusion.

  • Lower Fees

DEXs have a low fee structure, with exchanges like Uniswap charging around 0.3 percent. These prices change about network utilization, but they are still significantly less than the expenses of centralized alternatives

  • Privacy

Because wallets are held externally and the DEX is not responsible for the funds, traders using decentralized exchanges do not need to disclose their private keys. Users aren't often needed to undergo KYC and AML procedures when utilizing DEXs for the same reason.


Cons of DEXs

The drawbacks of using a decentralized exchange also pose a barrier to wider adoption. These flaws have an impact on DEX scalability, user experience, market liquidity, and capital movement. They are as follows;

  • Scalability

The number of transactions a blockchain network can process before attaining efficiency determines its scalability. Smart contracts that exist on blockchain networks power decentralized exchanges. As a result, DEXs are constrained by the limitations of their network architecture.

  • User Experience

DEXs are still in their infancy and can be difficult to navigate for those unfamiliar with decentralized blockchain technology. Users must first become familiar with external wallet platforms before interacting with a DEX. After that, they must fund their wallet with fiat or cryptocurrency. Finally, to conduct a deal, they must connect this wallet to the DEX interface. On a CEX, the process of depositing cash for trading is far more uncomplicated.

  • On-Ramps and Off-Ramps

Current DEX technology does not allow you to buy digital assets with fiat currency such as USD, nor can you trade fiat or withdraw money from your bank account. While stablecoin technology is evolving to replace currency in the Defi ecosystem, beginner users face a barrier to entry due to the lack of fiat on and off-ramps.


Final Words


Over the years, several of these decentralized exchanges have sprung up, each improving on past attempts to improve the user experience and create more robust trading platforms.
Finally, the concept appears to be highly associated with the ethos of self-sovereignty: consumers do not need to trust a third party, as they do with cryptocurrencies. Ethereum-based DEXs have witnessed a large increase in usage as a result of the rise of Defi. If the current trend continues, we may expect to see more technological innovation in the crypto-world.

articles.title: Proof of authority
articles.description:
What is Proof of Authority?


Proof of Authority (PoA) is a reputation-based consensus algorithm that introduces a practical and efficient solution for blockchain networks (especially the private ones).
 The term was proposed in 2017 by Ethereum co-founder and former CTO Gavin Wood.

The PoA consensus algorithm leverages the value of identities, which means that block validators are not staking coins but their reputation instead. Therefore, PoA blockchains are secured by the validating nodes that are arbitrarily selected as trustworthy entities.

The Proof of Authority model relies on a limited number of block validators and this is what makes it a highly scalable system. Blocks and transactions are verified by pre-approved participants, who act as moderators of the system.

PoA consensus algorithm may be applied in a variety of scenarios and is deemed a high-value option for logistical applications. When it comes to supply chains, for example, PoA is considered an effective and reasonable solution.

The Proof of Authority model enables companies to maintain their privacy while availing the benefits of blockchain technology. Microsoft Azure is another example where the PoA is being implemented. In a few words, the Azure platform provides solutions for private networks, with a system that does not require a native currency like the ether ‘gas’, since there is no need for mining.



Proof of Authority vs Proof of Stake

Some consider PoA to be a modified PoS, which leverages identity instead of coins. Due to the decentralized nature of most blockchain networks, PoS is not always suitable for certain businesses and corporations. In contrast, PoA systems may represent a better solution for private blockchains because their performance is considerably higher.



Conditions for Proof of Authority Consensus


Although the conditions may vary from system to system, the PoA consensus algorithm is usually reliant upon:


  • Valid and trustworthy identities: validators need to confirm their real identities.


  • Difficulty to become a validator: a candidate must be willing to invest money and put his reputation at stake. A tough process reduces the risks of selecting questionable validators and incentivizes a long-term commitment.


  • A standard for validator approval: the method for selecting validators must be equal to all candidates.


The essence behind the reputation mechanism is the certainty behind a validator’s identity. This can’t be an easy process nor one that would be readily given up. It must be capable of weeding out bad players. Finally, ensuring that all validators go through the same procedure guarantees the system’s integrity and reliability.



The Limitations

The perception of the PoA mechanism is that it foregoes decentralization. So, one could say that this model of consensus algorithm is just an effort to make centralized systems more efficient. While this makes PoA an attractive solution for large corporations with logistical needs, it does bring some hesitation — especially within the cryptocurrency scope. PoA systems do have a high throughput, but aspects of immutability come into question when things like censorship and blacklisting can be easily achieved.


Another common criticism is that the identities of PoA validators are visible to anyone. The argument against this is that only established players capable of holding this position would seek to become a validator (as a publicly known participant). Still, knowing the validators’ identities could potentially lead to third-party manipulation. For instance, if a competitor wants to disrupt a PoA-based network, he may try to influence public known validators to act dishonestly to compromise the system from within.


PoW, PoS, or PoA all have their unique advantages and disadvantages. It is well known that decentralization is highly valued within the cryptocurrency community and PoA, as a consensus mechanism, sacrifices decentralization to achieve high throughput and scalability. The inherent features of PoA systems are a stark contrast from how blockchains have been functioning until now. Still, PoA presents an interesting approach and cannot be disregarded as an emerging blockchain solution, which may suit well for private blockchain applications.

articles.title: What is a blockchain consensus algorithm?
articles.description:
Since its inception, many developers have gone to work to improve the blockchain and have ended up developing and releasing various forms of decentralized network consensus.


A consensus algorithm is a mechanism that allows users or machines to coordinate with each other in a distributed environment. You must ensure that all agents in the system can agree on a single source of truth, even if some of them fail. In other words, the system must be fault-tolerant.
In a centralized scheme, one entity has power over the entire system. In most cases, you can make any changes you want. There is no such thing as a complex management system for reaching consensus among many managers.

But in a decentralized scheme, the story changes completely. Suppose we are working with a distributed database, how do we agree on which records to add?

Overcoming such a challenge in an environment where outsiders do not trust each other was perhaps the most important achievement paving the way for blockchains.

In cryptocurrencies, user balances are saved in a database - blockchain. Each node (or each node in its place) must keep an equal copy of the database. Otherwise, you will soon receive conflicting information that will undermine the basic purpose of the cryptocurrency network.
Public key cryptography ensures that users cannot spend other people's coins. However, there is still a need for a single source of truth that users can rely on to find out if the funds have already been spent.

This consensus works like this: when some data enters the network, as it's not just currency transactions that go through there, it needs to be stored in a block. The miner that will store it needs to carry out the validation processes from its network algorithm with its pre-established rules. As soon as it validates, all other miners need to approve and make copies of this data, “giving body” to the block. Once completed, it is closed and permanently stored in the blockchain.

Likewise, the improvements we've cited above go through this kind of approval across the network. Miners evaluate and present proposals to the entire community. Once approved by everyone, it is implemented, but only after that. Thus, decentralization is guaranteed and the consensus proposed by the algorithm is reached.

Consensus mechanisms are critical to the functioning of distributed systems. Many believe that the greatest innovation in Bitcoin is the use of proof of work to allow users to agree on a common set of facts.

Modern consensus algorithms are based not only on digital money systems but also on blockchains, which allow developers to execute code on a distributed network. They form the backbone of blockchain technology today and are critical to the long-term viability of various existing networks.

Proof of work remains the core proposition of all consensus algorithms. A safer and more reliable alternative has not yet been proposed. That being said, there is a huge amount of research and development related to replacing PoW, and we are likely to see more in the coming years.

articles.title: What is a 51% attack?
articles.description:
A 51 percent attack happens when a single person or a group of people gains control over the majority of the hash rate on a blockchain network, thereby allowing the network to crash. In this case, the attacker would have enough mining power to omit or change the order of transactions on purpose.
They would be able to counteract transactions that had previously been completed while in control of the network, allowing them to double-spend bitcoin. They'd be unable to make new coins or alter existing blocks in any manner. Even if a 51% attack is successful, bitcoin or another blockchain-based currency is unlikely to be decimated.

How a 51% Attack Works


Because blockchains support Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, every transaction that happens on the network is documented in these digital files, which are available for inspection to all users. As a result, the same currency cannot be spent again.
A blockchain is made up of blocks, which are data bundles that store all executed transactions over a specific period, as the title indicates. A new bitcoin block is created every 10 minutes or so. A block cannot be updated once it has been completed or mined since a fraudulent version of the public ledger would be rapidly discovered and discarded by the network's users.
An attacker or a group of attackers could interrupt the process of generating new blocks by controlling the bulk of the computing power on the chain. They can prohibit other miners from generating blocks, theoretically giving them a monopoly on new block mining and all of the profits.

The Chances of a 51 % Attack Occurring


Because a blockchain is maintained by a distributed network of nodes, everyone interested in the consensus procedure collaborates. One of the reasons they are so safe is because of this. The safer a network is against manipulating data and attacks, the greater it is.
A 51 percent attack on the Bitcoin blockchain is often rare since an attacker's computational or hashing power would have to be greater than that of millions of miners around the world. To carry out such an attack, one would have to spend a significant amount of money on mining hardware that could compete with the rest of the network.
Even the largest and most powerful computers simply cannot compete with a pool of millions of other computers, making such an attack incredibly difficult. The cost of the electricity required to spread such an attack would also prove to be problematic.
That's not to say that a 51% attack can't be executed in a variety of ways. In other circumstances, a flaw in the blockchain's design might allow a miner to create new blocks faster, enabling them to launch a 51% attack. Meanwhile, 51% of attacks are prevalent to smaller blockchains with Proof of Work (PoW) systems because they require less computing power.

Prevention of 51% Attacks


By guaranteeing that no single miner, group of miners, or mining pool holds more than 50% of the processing power on the network, a single miner or group attempting to attack the Bitcoin network will be unable to overpower the longest existing and validated blockchain. Such a feat would necessitate massive amounts of hardware and energy. The potential criminal would also require some luck because of the volatility of the mining process.
A 51 percent attack on Bitcoin appears unlikely due to the network's size and hash rate. Many altcoins, on the other hand, are in grave danger. All it takes is a sizable initial expenditure and a sufficient amount of rental mining equipment that does not need to be connected.

articles.title: Proof of burn
articles.description:
Proof of burn Explanation


The Burn-Proof is the third attempt to create a system to deter fraudulent activity on a blockchain while improving how the blockchain works as a transaction tool.

Proof of work and proof of stake are also methods of preventing fraudulent activity on a blockchain; proof of work is the system used by the original and most popular cryptocurrency, Bitcoin.


How does the Proof of Burn consensus protocol work?


The Proof of Burn (PoB) consensus protocol has a very special way of reaching consensus and validating transactions within the blockchain. The miners must send cryptocurrencies to a public and verifiable address. This address is known as the Eater's Address o Dining Address, from which they will never be able to obtain it again. In other words, miners have to make some sort of blockchain investment with cryptocurrencies. And the higher the number of cryptocurrencies burnt on the network, the higher the mining power reached by the miner.

In other words, miners must invest in blockchain to demonstrate their commitment to the network. In this sense, this protocol is closely related to Proof of Work (PoW). The difference is that miners shouldn't invest in powerful and expensive computer equipment but tokens and cryptocurrencies.

In this way, in the Proof of Burn (PoB), the burnt cryptocurrencies will be unusable and inaccessible to any user. This is because the addresses of the eaters are randomly created and are not associated with any known private key. Thus, cryptocurrencies cannot be recovered once they are sent to these addresses.



Pros and Cons of Proof of Burn


Although concepts and opinions on this protocol vary widely depending on the user, in a general sense, the main advantages and disadvantages of implementing this consensus algorithm can be cited.


Benefits/Pros of Proof of Burn


  • Proof of Burn (PoB) does not require an excessive amount of energy or computing power. Therefore, it is believed that this protocol, as long as you are not using 100% renewable energy, is much more sustainable and environmentally friendly.
  • The process of burning tokens and cryptocurrencies is done virtually therefore, no mining equipment or hardware is required to burn cryptocurrencies. Centralized hardware companies are eliminated, creating an imbalance of advantages in the sector.
  • Proof of Burn (PoB) ensures network stability and security, by encouraging miners to invest (burn) with coins and tokens. This, therefore, guarantees the honest and reliable behavior of the miners in the network, who do not want to lose their investments.
  • In addition, promotes the long-term commitment of investors in the project, which in turn maintains and ensures price stability.
  • This protocol can also be used to add value to a new token under development or to burn unsold cryptocurrencies in ICOs.
  • Proof of Burn (PoB) also makes it easier to distribute tokens and cryptocurrencies in a much more decentralized and fair manner.


Cons of Proof of Burn


  • Depending on the system, tokens to be burned can come from other cryptocurrencies (such as Bitcoin) or other Proof of Work (PoW) processes. A factor that, for many, makes this protocol less environmentally friendly.
  • The process of checking the work done by each miner is much slower than that done in Proof of Work (PoW).
  • Without any guarantee of recovering the values ​​of burnt cryptocurrencies or tokens, users of Proof of Burn (PoB) face a risk similar to that of investing.

articles.title: What are wrapped tokens
articles.description:
Wrapped tokens are cryptocurrency tokens whose value is tied to the value of another coin. The term "wrapped token" refers to the fact that the original asset is enclosed in a wrapper, a kind of digital vault that enables the creation of the wrapped version on another blockchain.


What Is A Wrapped Token?


A wrapped token is a cryptocurrency that has been tokenized. It is usually linked to the asset's value and may be redeemed for it at any time. It is often used to represent an asset that does not exist natively on the blockchain on which it is issued.
Consider a wrapped token to be comparable to a stable coin in that its value is determined by another asset. In the case of a stable coin, this is often fiat money. In most cases, a wrapped token is a native asset on another network.
Due to the fact that blockchains are separate systems, there is no efficient method to transfer data between them. Wrapped tokens provide interoperability between various blockchains by allowing the underlying tokens to act as a bridge between them.
It's worth emphasizing that as a regular user, you won't need to worry about the wrapping and unwrapping process; you may just trade wrapped tokens like any other cryptocurrency. For instance, the Binance WBTC/BTC market.
What Are Wrapped Tokens And How Do They Work?
As an example, consider Wrapped Bitcoin (WBTC), an Ethereum-based tokenized version of Bitcoin. WBTC is an ERC-20 token with a one-to-one peg to Bitcoin, enabling for effective usage of Bitcoin on the Ethereum network.
Typically, wrapped tokens need a custodian - an entity that retains an equal quantity of the underlying asset to the wrapped amount. This custodian may be a merchant, a multisig wallet, a decentralized autonomous organization (DAO), or even a smart contract. Thus, in the case of WBTC, the custodian must retain 1 BTC for every 1 WBTC produced. On-chain evidence of this reserve exists.


However, how does the process of wrapping work? A merchant pays bitcoins to the custodian, who mints them. After that, the custodian mints WBTC on Ethereum in proportion to the quantity of BTC supplied. When the merchant wishes to convert the WBTC to BTC, the merchant submits a burn request to the custodian, who then releases the BTC from the reserves. Consider the custodian as the packager and unpacker. In the instance of WBTC, a DAO is responsible for adding and deleting custodians and merchants.
While some members of the cryptocurrency community may refer to Tether (USDT) as a wrapped token, this is not the case. While USDT typically trades on a one-to-one basis with USD, Tether does not retain an exact amount of real USD for each USDT in its reserves. Rather than that, this reserve is composed of cash and other real-world cash equivalents, assets, and loan receivables. However, the concept is very similar. Each USDT token functions as a wrapper for a currency USD.

articles.title: What are smart contracts?
articles.description:
Smart contracts are virtual contracts that are created automatically when preset terms and conditions are achieved and are maintained on a blockchain. They are often used to automate the implementation of a contract so that all parties can be certain of the conclusion right away, without the involvement of any third party.
They can also regulate a workflow, starting the next step when certain conditions are achieved. Also, smart contracts not only describe the rules and sanctions that govern a contract in the same manner that conventional contracts do, but they also implement those rules and sanctions automatically. Contracts regarding payment authorization or a utility meter reading threshold are typical ways of describing simple contracts.

How Smart Contracts Operate

A smart contract is a form of application that deals with the encryption of business logic. It operates on a dedicated virtual machine that is embedded in blockchain technology or any other form of a distributed ledger. This contract involves business teams connecting with programmers to establish their expectations for the smart contract's target outcomes in response to distinct events or details, which is the first step in the process of developing a smart contract.

Therein, the developers create the logic and verify it on a smart contract programming platform to check that it works as expected. After the program is inscribed, it is conveyed to a security review team for assessment. Meanwhile, an institutional expert or a firm that specializes in assessing smart contract security could be used while the process is ongoing. The contract is then installed on an existing blockchain or other distributed ledger infrastructure once it has been authorized.

The smart contract is usually set up to wait for contract updates from an oracle. This oracle is effectively a cryptographically continuous data source, once it has been installed. However, once it obtains the necessary combination of data from one or more oracles, the smart contract then activates.


Benefits of Smart Contracts

There are lots of benefits users get to see while using smart contracts. Let's have a look at them below:

1. Transparency and Trust
One of the key benefits of smart contracts is that there's no need to worry about information being meddled with for personal interest because there is no third party engaged, and encrypted transaction logs are traded among partakers.

2. Security and Encryption
Because blockchain transaction records are encrypted, they are extremely difficult to hack. Furthermore, because each record on a distributed ledger is linked to the preceding and consecutive entries, attackers would have to create a unique chain to change a solitary record. This makes smart contracts to be highly secured and protected.

3. Cost-effectiveness
Another key benefit of smart contracts is that they have the potential to automate cross-organizational business policies. Because of this, several operating costs can be saved.

4. Level of Speed
Smart contracts can also speed up the processing of commercial protocols that span various institutions.

5. Autonomy
Smart contracts are usually executed autonomously by the system. Hence, eliminating the need for an intermediary to oversee commercial transactions.


What The Future Holds for Smart Contracts


Smart contracts are twisted, and their usefulness stretches far beyond transferring assets. They can conduct transactions in a wide spectrum of industries, including legal proceedings, insurance rewards, and many others. These contracts have the prospect to exclude the need of a third party in the legal and financial realms by facilitating and automating conventional and duplicative operations for which customers nowadays disburse huge fees to banks and attorneys.
These contracts have also shown potential in optimizing IoT and edge computing tasks. Also, incorporating smart contracts into vending machines that circulate stocks in response to cryptocurrency payments is another prospective use case. All these have made the future of Smart Contracts incredible.

articles.title: Selfish mining attack
articles.description:
Mechanism


Selfish mining is an attack where a miner manipulates the rules of a blockchain in order

to gain more than their fair share of mining rewards. It happens when a miner, or mining pool,

mines blocks privately with the intention of building a longer chain, and eventually making the

blocks public, therefore uncling all blocks previously mined publicly, and claiming all block

rewards. This is possible as honest miners immediately make their blocks public, and will default

to the longest chain, though it requires a significant amount of hash power on the selfish miner’s

part in order to be profitable.


Are selfish mining attacks a problem?


Though selfish mining attacks are theoretically possible, there is an open question on if

blockchain users and miners should actually be concerned about them. To this day, there has

been no major instance of such an attack, and to execute one would be both extremely

resource-intensive and potentially risky for the attacker.


In research on the Markov chain model, it is estimated that a successful selfish miner

attack would require a minimum of 22% of a network’s hashpower to be profitable after 51

rounds of difficulty adjustments, but would require 33% to be profitable in a more reasonable 5

rounds, or 70 days of bitcoin mining (golden.com). On the Bitcoin network, and other large

networks, maintaining these levels for large periods of time would be very hard for a miner, as

even in the short term mining pools rarely go over 15% of hashpower. However even with

slightly less power, a selfish miner may be able to put pressure on other miners by reducing

rewards, and acquire a larger share of hash power by forcing others out. This is more of a

concern for a smaller, less established network. But even an unprofitable selfish miner that is

growing its resources puts a network at risk for a larger attack, with the worst-case scenario

being the more devastating 51% attack.


However, this is again, highly unlikely for established networks. Even in a case where a

mining attacker succeeded in an attack, they would harm the economic value of the network,

and therefor make their rewards worth less. This would likely make the point of the attack moot

if it was for profit, but may still leave the vector open for a purely destructive actor.


Solutions

If selfish mining is a concern, there are potential options for closing the attack vector.
One option would be to randomly assign miners whenever a blockchain is forked. This would
redistribute rewards for the selfish miner’s privately mined blocks, therefore eliminate the profit
motive. Another solution would be to create a limit on a mining pool’s hashpower, though this
may be easily circumventable if it was implemented in a way that maintained maximum
decentralization.

Selfish Mining - Theoetically possibility, but unlikely to be a problem
As it says on the tin, selfish mining is mostly a theoretical problem. In practice it would be
extremely difficult to accomplish on an established network, and cause economic problems for
the attacker if it did succeed. If one is to imagine a successful attack, they must imagine an
attacker with no profit incentive or no regard for profit, and more spare computing power than
some of the largest pools combined, and with this power available for long periods of time. This
is an incredibly unlikely scenario, but still worth thinking about, if only to understand the
theoretical shortcomings of blockchain technology.

articles.title: Blockchain oracles explained
articles.description:
Blockchain oracles serve as the intermediaries between the blockchains and the outside world. They are third-party services that provide smart contracts with external information. 

Blockchains Oracles come in in a situation where blockchains and smart contracts are restricted access to off-chain data, i.e., data outside the network.  To fulfill any contractual agreements, it becomes essential to have relevant information from the outside world. In this way, the agreements would be easily executed.

In this way, Blockchains Oracles help in the provision of a link between off-chain and on-chain data. In this way, Oracles broaden the scope in which smart contracts can operate. Thus, without blockchain oracles, smart contracts would have minimal use as they would have been restricted to only data from within their networks. 

So, a blockchain oracle is not the data source itself but the layer that queries, verifies, and authenticates external data sources. 

Meanwhile, some of the data transmitted by oracles include price information, the successful completion of a payment, or the temperature measured by a sensor. 

What will it take to call data from the outside world? Once the smart contract is invoked, the network resources have to be spent.

Some oracles go beyond relaying information on smart contracts but send it back to external sources.


How Smart Oracle operates

Smart Oracles operate in different ways on a blockchain. Since there are many different types, its operation depends on what it is designed for. 
Note that without the relay of data by oracle, there is no way to settle an agreement between two or more parties in a deal.


Software oracles

The Software oracles interact with online sources of information before transmitting it to the blockchain. The sources of this information include online databases, servers, websites – essentially, any data source on the Web. Thus, the supply information to smart contracts is transmitted in real-time. 
Hardware oracles
Here the smart contracts interface with the real world. Thus, Hardware oracles get information from the physical world and make it available to smart contracts. The information is relayed from electronic sensors, barcode scanners, and other information-reading devices.  


Inbound Oracles

These also transmit information from external sources to smart contracts.
A smart contract that tells what a sensor measures the temperature is an example of an inbound oracle.
Outbound oracles
These transmit information from smart contracts to the external world. 
Outbound oracle can be considered with a smart lock. Here, the smart contract sends the information through an outbound oracle to a mechanism that unlocks the smart lock.
Centralized Oracles
As the name connotes, the oracle is controlled by a single entity. This means it is the sole provider of information for the smart contract. 
Decentralized Oracles
