These are seen to be public blockchains meant to avoid counterparty risk. Information shared here is reliable because they are not from a single source of truth.  
Other types of blockchain oracles include Contract-specific oracles and Human oracles. These should be easily understood from their names.

articles.title: Staking
articles.description:
Staking is part of the initiative introduced in the digital currency industry as a reward to a user who contributed to the network. The user earns an additional cryptocurrency for such an effort.
Other forms of rewards include inflation, savings rates, etc. The exchanges like Coinbase allow customers to benefit from these protocols and then pass on the rewards to eligible customers who have opted into the feature.
A customer who participates actively in transaction validation (similar to mining) on a proof-of-stake (PoS) blockchain has a chance of being rewarded. That is what staking is about in simple and clear terms. So, using such blockchain with a minimum-required balance of a specific cryptocurrency gives you the chance to validate transactions and earn Staking rewards. 
All in all, staking involves holding funds in a cryptocurrency wallet to support the security and operations of a blockchain network.
Before going into how staking works, there is a need to understand how Proof of Stake (PoS). This consensus mechanism allows blockchains to operate more energy-efficiently while maintaining a decent degree of decentralization works. 
It is believed that you are not a novice to how Bitcoin works. It, therefore, means that you are familiar with Proof of Work (PoW) - the mechanism that allows transactions to be gathered into blocks, which are then linked together to create the blockchain. 
So, here, you can lock your coins (your “stake”) and at particular intervals while the protocol randomly assigns the right to validate the next block. The condition here is that the probability of being chosen is proportional to the amount of coins, meaning the more coins you locked up, the higher your chances of getting rewarded.


How does staking work?


As stated earlier, to qualify for stake rewards, you must have the minimum balance. Once that condition is met, a node deposits that amount of cryptocurrency into the network as a stake, similar to a security deposit. On the blockchains, the size of a stake determines the chances of that node being chosen to forge the next block. 

You will be rewarded provided the node successfully creates a block similar to how a miner is rewarded in proof-of-work chains. However, a validator will lose part of his/her stake if they double-sign or attempt to attack the network.

Inflation in the normal financial clime refers to a situation whereby the purchasing power of a given currency over time declines. But in the cryptocurrency arena, assets such as Algorand (ALGO) earn rewards via inflation or community rewards. Inflation leads to new tokens being added to the network at a rate determined by the protocol. The tokens are subsequently distributed to holders as rewards.

In this way, blocks will be produced without relying on specialized mining hardware, such as ASICs, which requires a significant investment in hardware. 

Staking is a direct investment in the cryptocurrency itself, removing the stress of you competing for the next block with computational work since PoS validators are selected based on the number of coins they are staking.

articles.title: Symmetric vs asymmetric encryption
articles.description:
Presently, there are two types of data encryption in use. They are symmetric and asymmetric encryption. Understanding the differences between symmetric and asymmetric encryption, as well as how these processes work in the daily transfer of information, is very important. However, the distinctions between symmetric and asymmetric encryption will be discussed in this guide. So, without much further ado, let's get started by doing a proper introduction of these two data encryptions.


Asymmetric Encryption

Asymmetric encryption is a type of data encryption that involves the encryption of data between two parties that use two distinct but mathematically linked keys rather than a single key. In asymmetric encryption, the first key encrypts your data before sending it over the internet, while the other key decrypts it at the opposite end of the transaction. The first key and the second key are known, and the public and private keys respectively. As a result of this, Asymmetric encryption can also be referred to as public-key encryption.


Symmetric Encryption


Symmetric encryption is a type of digital encryption that involves the encryption and decryption of data that uses only one secret key rather than two. In symmetric encryption, the sender and the recipient each have an identical copy of the key, which they keep to themselves. As a result, symmetric encryption can also be referred to as private key encryption.
The Differences Between Symmetric and Asymmetric Encryption
Having known what these two data encryptions are, let's quickly spot out their differences. In terms of how they work and where they are most valuable, symmetric and asymmetric encryption differs in several crucial ways. They include

1. The Cryptographic Keys' Number, Nature, and Size
In Asymmetric encryption, the public and private keys are mathematically linked but unique, whereas, in symmetric encryption, the public and private keys are identical. Symmetric keys are generally typically shorter than their asymmetric counterparts in terms of length. Whereas asymmetric keys should be about 2048 bits or larger.

2. The Distribution of Keys
In asymmetric encryption, exchanging keys across digital public channels isn't a problem. This is because asymmetric key exchange protocols were created specifically for that purpose. Whereas, in symmetric encryption, you would have to meet someone offline to safely exchange the keys. This is not only inconvenient, but it also defeats the point of digital communication in the first place.

3. The Types and Intricacies of Encryption Algorithm
The types of encryption algorithms employed in each process are one of the major differences between symmetric and asymmetric encryption. In Symmetric encryption, the algorithms employed include DES, 3DES, AES, and other methods that are either block ciphers or stream ciphers. Whereas, in asymmetric encryption, the algorithms include RSA, DSA, and ECC, among others.

4. Time Consumed
Symmetric encryption is usually suitable for large organizations that need to encrypt significant amounts of data because it is very fast, and it utilizes only one key. Whereas asymmetric encryption encrypts and decrypts data using two independent keys and more complex algorithms, making it slower to encrypt and decrypt high volumes of data. 

5. Suitability for Use in Public/Private Channels 
For private channels, symmetric encryption is usually preferable, and for public channels, asymmetric encryption is the better choice. In reality, this is one of the ways of thinking about the distinctions between these two data encryptions.


Conclusion


The points highlighted above are the major ones to consider while distinguishing between these two data encryptions. Symmetric encryption is usually faster and easier to use, although it is often seen as less safe compared to asymmetric encryption. Because of the shorter key lengths, symmetric encryption is substantially faster to utilize. Because of its longer key lengths and sophisticated algorithms, asymmetric encryption has a propensity to slow down networks. Therefore, when determining the sort of encryption to use, these are the considerations to think about.

articles.title: What is synthetix (SNX)?
articles.description:
SNX is one of the cryptocurrencies operating on the Ethereum blockchain, powering the Synthetix protocol, enabling synthetic trading assets on Ethereum. 
Within the Ethereum blockchain, the tokens provide exposure to synthetic assets such as gold, Bitcoin, U.S. Dollars, TESLA, and AAPL.
Before going further, it is important to note that synthetic assets are financial instruments in the form of ERC-20 smart contracts known as "Synths." They track and provide the returns of another asset without any user holding such asset.
Thus, Synthetix protocol enables the issuance of synthetic assets on the Ethereum blockchain. Here non-blockchain-based assets are exposed to the crypto ecosystem, thus creating a more mature financial market.
All Synths traders trading cryptocurrencies, indexes, inverses, and real-world assets like gold on Kwenta, Synthetix's decentralized exchange (DEX), can use the platform.  They can also use Synthetix's native token, known as the Synthetix Network Token (SNX), to provide collateral against Synths issued.


How Does Synthetix Work?


Synths operate with the use of decentralized oracles, which are smart contract-based price discovery protocols. In this way, they track the prices of the assets represented. You are allowed to hold and exchange Synths as if you own the underlying assets.

Thus, Synths bring those holding assets that are normally inaccessible to the average crypto investor, like gold and silver on board. In this way, the protocols allow you to trade them quickly and efficiently. 

Synths can be deposited on other DeFi platforms such as Curve and Uniswap because they are issued on Ethereum. Thus, traders can use them to provide liquidity and earn interest.  In this way, it helps build mature markets that facilitate price discovery which would work against volatility. 

The protocol provides options contracts that allow you to stay afloat in a situation whereby you anticipate that the value of your asset will rise in the future but are hesitant to accept the risk that could result in the asset's value failing to rise.

The options contracts are agreements between two parties between a buyer and a seller, which gives them the option to buy or sell an asset at a future date at a predetermined price. 


Meanwhile, there are two methods to trading Synthetix network. You either purchase an Ethereum token on an exchange or exchange it for sUSD on Kwenta. You can also exchange for other Synths, such as sBTC, to trade as well.

All Synths created by staking SNX tokens are backed by a 600% collateralization ratio on this platform. The ratio is determined through community governance. 

Meanwhile, some situations will occur when you stake SNX and mint sUSD. Doing this process means that you have decided to take on debt reflecting the amount of sUSD that must be burned to un-stake your SNX.  The debt represents a proportion of all the debt on Synthetix, and it is denominated in sUSD.

It could either increase and decrease in accordance with the supply of Synths and their exchange rates.

articles.title: Tendermint explained
articles.description:
Tendermint is open-source software that enables the creation of blockchains and the development of apps in any language. Even better, they are interoperable with other blockchains.
Tendermint is a low-level protocol that is divided into two components: a blockchain consensus engine and a flexible application interface. It is intended to be a tool that developers can utilize to bypass the tedious and technical aspects of encryption and instead focus on higher-level blockchain and application development.


Introduction

Creating a cryptocurrency or blockchain network is much more time consuming than initializing a database. It necessitates an artful balancing of incentives and trade-offs between security, decentralization, and scalability.

Unsurprisingly, companies seeking to create the best blockchain ecosystems have experimented with a variety of different methods.


Tendermint

Much of Tendermint will feel familiar if you're acquainted with blockchain technology. 


Recognize The Blockchain Architecture


Tendermint is a distributed ledger technology stack. However, Bitcoin and Ethereum are. Bear in mind that blockchain technology is not only about the blockchain database; it is also about the peer-to-peer network of nodes, how they interact, and the exciting things you can do with transactions and smart contracts. The objective here is to get everyone to agree on a state.
The majority of today's main blockchains have invented the secret sauce that enables this. They often, however, rely on monolithic architecture, a term in software engineering that refers to components that are linked and interdependent. You couldn't just cut a piece off and connect it into another device.
Monolithic architecture is inflexible. In contrast, with a modular design, you may change individual components without fear of destroying everything. When you update a single component in a monolithic structure, you must guarantee that all other components stay compatible.


Core of Tendermint

The words "Tendermint" and "Tendermint Core" interchangeably in this section since we're primarily concerned with the technology.

Tendermint, on the other hand, is the name of the business while Tendermint Core is the name of the program on which the company works. More precisely, the software is composed of two main components: the Tendermint Core consensus engine and the application interface (ABCI).

Tendermint Core is a fault-tolerant system. In essence, it's a large, distributed computer that displays the same status to everyone simultaneously. 

To begin, the consensus method utilized is one based on Proof of Stake (PoS). Each period, a random node is chosen from a validator set. That node is then required to propose the next block. If the other validators agree, the new block is added to the chain and the chain is updated. Finality is instantaneous - unlike Bitcoin or Ethereum, there is no need to wait for confirmations to ensure the validity of your transaction.

However, there is more! The design of Tendermint Core is modular, with the application layer being distinct from the consensus and networking layers. That is, you may insert your own application layer into the stack. There is no need to be concerned about pernicious incentives or consensus algorithms.

Perhaps this is not exciting enough for the end user. However, for developers, the ability to use an established framework enables them to immediately begin developing apps without having to bootstrap a whole network. The integrated layer may stream data from the blockchain, allowing developers to build applications in any language.

The magic occurs via the use of something called the Application Blockchain Interface, or ABCI for short. Consider the GPIO pins of a Raspberry Pi computer. You may connect them to a variety of third-party components, from LEDs to complex watering systems for your plants. Similarly, the ABCI is what separates the blockchain from the apps that operate on top of it.


What Makes Tendermint Core So Special?


Because the application interface and consensus mechanism are separated, a variety of decentralized apps may integrate any programming language into their business logic.
To see what is possible, look no farther than Ethermint: a project that took the Ethereum codebase, eliminated the Proof of Work mechanism, and attached the Ethereum Virtual Machine to Tendermint.


Concluding remarks

Tendermint's blockchain engine has attracted the interest of a broad range of cryptocurrency stakeholders, from developers to end users.

If the software continues to gain momentum, it has the potential to serve as the backbone for a blockchain-based internet.

articles.title: The basics of sharding
articles.description:
Have you tried to do your research about Sharding, and what you found out was a tad bit too complicated? You’ll be happy to know that you’ve found the article that explains the ABC of sharding. 
The concept of sharding is derived from the word shard, which means a small part of a whole.  Each of these shards is independent and distinct from other shards, and it has its data. Sharding, in this context, can be defined as a method whereby a single logical dataset is being split and stored in a couple of databases. Read on to find out more about Sharding and the concept behind how it works.


What is Sharding?


Sharding is the process whereby the data in a database is being parted. In this process, large tables are broken up into multiple smaller tables. At the end of the process, the data ends up being divided into smaller parts or chunks that are officially called shards. 

It is important to understand that each of these shards is unique, distinct, independent of each other, and they all have the same schema and columns. Much like the original table before the sharding. A shard could be anything, from data to a physical database held on a separate database.


How is Sharding Done?


Sharding is done by the horizontal partitioning of data into rows of the same table in multiple database nodes. This is why Sharding is also known as horizontal partitioning. The only difference between horizontal and vertical partitioning is the traditional tabular view of a database.

Depending on the goals you have for the database, such as the prevention of data loss, different techniques can be used for the sharding process. Some of them are range-based sharding, hash-based sharding, geo-based sharding, and directory-based sharding, 


Types of Sharding

There are two common types of sharding. They are;

1. Horizontal Sharding
This type of sharding is more effective when the queries return a subset of rows that are organized in a common group. The data in this database appears only in single shards.

2. Vertical Sharding
This type of sharding is more effective when the queries return only a subset of columns of the data. In this type of sharding, the data in the database stays present in all the shards.


Why is Sharding Important?


Sharding helps to optimize database management systems. Sharding is important because it helps store large data in multiple nodes to give horizontal scalability and improved performance. Sharded databases offer high levels of availability, and that is one of its benefits. It is similar to partitioning, but they are slightly different.

Through sharding, your application will make fewer inquiries. This way the application doesn’t get strained by searching through a large amount of data, unlike some situations where the application has to go through the entire database, causing a major setback. This means that you will experience a faster query response time.

Sharding generally improves the performance of your application, so you do not have to worry about scalability issues. Database sharding helps to facilitate scaling. It also helps to improve the latency of the network. This is done by splitting the blockchain network into distinct and separate shards.

Sharding has a lot of advantages, especially because, with database sharding, you will enjoy lower costs, but it should only be done when the amount of data you are dealing with is very large. It’s a good idea to use sharding if the amount of data has passed the ability of the server or if the number of reading/writing requests is more than the ability of a single node.

articles.title: The lightning network: a beginner's guide
articles.description:
What is Lightning Network?

The Lightning Network is not another fork, separate blockchain, or new coin, but simply a second layer of the Bitcoin network enabling fast and inexpensive person-to-person transactions through a Lightning channel.


How does the Lightning Network work?


The Lightning Network can process payments quickly and cheaply by opening a "channel". A channel enables two parties to send and receive Bitcoin from one another. You can do this as many times as you want, and when you're done, you can decide to close the channel. This will update the main Bitcoin blockchain with the correct balances of both parties and record everything as just a single transaction. The best thing about these channels is that they work much like a large network. If you want to send bitcoin to someone but don't have a channel open, you can send the bitcoin and it will go through existing channels until it reaches its destination. The more channels that are open, the easier it becomes to transact with people.



Problems with the Lightning network


  • Centralization


Chances are that large intermediaries that people do business with often become large hubs for Lightning Network payments. This is not a problem for making payments easier. However, if a large number of transactions are using the same channels, a large part of the network can collapse if those channels are hacked or crashed.


  • Adoption


Currently, the Lightning Network is not easy or intuitive to use for beginners. Just like Bitcoin, this makes adoption slow as it is not easily accessible to many people either. You are limited concerning the usage of the Lightning Network. In the absence of a large system in place yet, everyone you want to send Bitcoin to needs to have an open channel with them. Opening a channel is complicated and time-consuming, so it's not a friendly option for most people.

Why is the Lightning Network necessary?


So, a long way, the Lightning Network (or truly, LN) appears to be the most realistic technique to scaling the Bitcoin blockchain. Coordinating modifications in this kind of considerable ecosystem is tricky –  there’s a chance of difficult forks and potentially catastrophic insects. With a lot of fees at stake, experimentation is distinctly dangerous.

When you move that experimentation far from the blockchain, you have got loads greater flexibility. If something goes incorrect, it’ll have no impact on the real Bitcoin network. Layer answers don’t undermine any of the security assumptions that have saved the protocol going for 10+ years.


The benefits


Here is how it works. If you have a chum or enterprise acquaintance with whom you change loads of Bitcoin, you may jointly comply with open a Lightning wallet.


  • This wallet would belong to both of you - called a multi-signature wallet - and when you open it, you would each put an amount in it that was held as a balance in the wallet. Maybe one or two bitcoins each.


  • If you needed to pay for your knowledge, you transfer what you need in the wallet to them. The wallet keeps a running account of both-way transactions, without the need to publish these transactions on the blockchain and wait for them to be verified each time.


  • It is only after the wallet is closed that the transactions will be published on the blockchain.


  • When two people open a Lightning wallet, they've created a Lightning channel between them. So why is it called a network? Each person who They don't have just one person they are connected to, but many channels connect to many different people, like spokes in a hub.


  • If you wanted to send bitcoins to an acquaintance of an acquaintance, you wouldn't need to set up another channel. Since all of these channels now create an interconnected network, you can simply go through the network.


  • The possibility of fraud can arise if an acquaintance wishes to close a Lightning wallet to a prior equilibrium that favors them. But if that happens, you can spread the malicious activity on the Bitcoin network and, with the list of transactions in the Lightning wallet, prove that the settlement is not correct.


  • To be part of this network, you need to set up a Lightning Node, which is free software that runs on your computer or phone that lets you open and close channels.


  • But you don't necessarily need to exchange payments with him. You can run your node to become a router for others and to help move transactions over the Lightning network.


  • What it solves and what it can create
  • As you can probably already see from this explanation, Lightning Network solves the scalability issue by allowing transactions to occur outside of the blockchain.


  • Transactions can now happen instantly, with very little cost, allowing for fast, day-to-day use and functionality - and it stays decentralized and trustless.


  • But what excites me the most is that the Lightning Network allows you to do microtransactions, even for a penny. This can override subscription models or even remove them.


  • You can just pay pennies to read an article, or pay per second when watching a movie on Netflix or YouTube, or pay per kilobytes through a VPN.


  • Transfers of as little as pennies could happen immediately through the Lightning Network, and wouldn't need to be verified every time on the blockchain. They could be checked once at a later date, making everything run much easier and faster.


  • Micropayments also have excellent applications in the Internet of Things. Someday our devices or machines will be able to transact without us, and if our refrigerator needs to order milk or eggs, the Lightning Network can facilitate these types of transactions on the fly securely and easily.

articles.title: Uniswap
articles.description:
Uniswap is one of the decentralized finance protocols used in the exchange of cryptocurrencies.

The name Uniswap emanated from the company itself, whose primary responsibility was to build the Uniswap protocol, which facilitates automated transactions between cryptocurrency tokens on the Ethereum blockchain. This is achieved through the use of smart contracts.

Finding as of October 2020 show Uniswap to be the largest decentralized exchange and the fourth-largest cryptocurrency exchange overall in terms of the daily trading volume. During this period, its average daily trading volume was US$220.

The finance protocol continued to wax stronger as it was seen to have generated fees of approximately US$2–3 million daily for the liquidity providers who facilitate liquid markets for the cryptocurrencies being exchanged as of March 2021.


Emergence of Uniswap


Uniswap is an initiative of Hayden Adams, a former mechanical engineer at Siemens. Adam created the financial protocol on November 2, 2018.  The outfit grows bigger by acquiring the assets from venture capital firms, including Andreessen Horowitz, Paradigm Venture Capital, Union Square Ventures LLC, and ParaFi. 


With such a huge trading volume, traders and investors rely on Uniswap because of its usage in decentralized finance (DeFi).

Uniswap survived hacking in April 2020. Unfortunately, this action led to its website being taken down temporarily as the hackers attempted to use a reentrancy hack on the exchange but were unsuccessful.


How do Uniswap works?


A decentralized finance protocol used to exchange cryptocurrencies and tokens Uniswap is provided on decentralized blockchain networks. The protocol runs on open-source software, in contrast to any centralized intermediary. Some of the cryptocurrency exchanges run by centralized companies include Coinbase, Binance, and OKEx.


If there is a need for changes to the protocol, owners of native cryptocurrency and governance tokens called UNI would have to vote for such action. The decision s then implemented by a team of developers. 


Early users of Uniswap got UNI coins, and each Ethereum address that had interacted with Uniswap before September 1, 2020, could claim 400 UNI tokens (worth approximately $1,400 at the time).  As of October 2020, the market capitalization for the UNI token was over $500 million.


The Uniswap financial protocol makes use of liquidity pools rather than serving as a market maker, which makes it also to be different from centralized exchanges. The aim of this is to create more efficient markets.


Individuals and bots referred to as liquidity providers, provide liquidity to the exchange by adding a pair of tokens to a smart contract. These can then be bought and sold by other users.


In this way, liquidity providers get a certain percentage of the trading fees earned for that trading pair, which is a certain amount of tokens removed from the pool for an amount of the other token. This leads to a change in price. 


Since the protocol uses the Ethereum blockchain, many tokens are accessible, and there are no fees required to list tokens. There is no need for registration for users as well, which aids anonymity.

articles.title: What are flash loans in DeFi
articles.description:
A flash loan is a relatively new type of unsecured lending that has become popular in a number of  DeFi (Decentralized Finance) protocols based on the Ethereum network.


These types of loans have made headlines lately for being used to exploit a number of vulnerable DeFi protocols, resulting in millions of dollars in losses. However, proponents argue that flash lending introduces an innovative and useful tool for arbitrage and quick deals in the financial world that wasn't possible before blockchains.


Most of us are familiar with normal loans. A lender lends money to a borrower in order to eventually repay it in full. The lender receives a payout from the borrower for temporarily separating their money.


Flash loans are similar but have the following unique characteristics:

  • Smart Contracts: Flash Loans use smart contracts, tools that are activated by a blockchain and that don't allow funds to change hands if certain rules are not followed. In the case of a flash loan, the rule applies that the borrower must repay the loan before the transaction is completed, otherwise the smart contract cancels the transaction - so it is as if the loan did not come about at all.

  • Unsecured Loan: Oftentimes, lenders require borrowers to provide collateral to ensure that the lender can still get their money back if the borrower cannot repay the loan. However, no collateral is required with an unsecured loan. This lack of collateral does not mean that the flash loan lender will not get their money back. It's just sent back differently. Instead of offering collateral, the borrower has to repay the money immediately, which brings us to our next point.

  • Immediate: Usually getting and completing a loan is a long process. Typically, when a borrower is approved for a loan, they must continuously repay it for months or years. However, a flash loan is available immediately. The smart contract for the loan must be fulfilled in the same transaction in which it is loaned. This means that the borrower will have to use other smart contracts to do instant deals on the loaned capital before the transaction ends, which usually takes a few seconds.



This type of loan can be useful in certain cases, such as: for traders who want to quickly benefit from arbitrage opportunities when two markets value a cryptocurrency differently.


The Aave Ethereum lending platform pioneered the idea in early 2020. The concept is new and still has many problems as new hacks become apparent. “There is no real analogy to flash loans”, as the Ethereum lending platform Aave puts it in its documentation.


Why Should I Want To Use A Flash Loan?


In short, this is a way to make potentially significant profits without risking your own money.

There are times when the outrageous speed of a flash loan makes sense.

Flash loans can be used for:

  • Arbitrage: Traders can make money by looking for price differences on different exchanges. Suppose two markets value Pizzacoin differently. The price is $ 1 on Exchange A and $ 2 on Exchange B. A user can use a flash loan and call a separate smart contract to buy 100 pizzacoins for $ 100 on Exchange A and then get them on Exchange B for 200 USD for sale. The borrower then pays the back loan and pockets the difference.


  • Collateral Swaps: Quickly swap the collateral for the user's loan for a different type of collateral.


  • Lower Transaction Fees: In a sense, flash loans roll, which usually involves multiple transactions in one. Each transaction costs a fee, so flash loans may mean lower fees.

glossaries.title: Address
glossaries.teaser: An address can be thought of as a bank account number for a specific cryptocurrency asset, and usually comes in the form of a string of letters and numbers.. The cryptocurrency can be sent to
glossaries.description: An address can be thought of as a bank account number for a specific cryptocurrency asset, and usually comes in the form of a string of letters and numbers.. The cryptocurrency can be sent to and from the address.

glossaries.title: Adoption Curve
glossaries.teaser: The adoption curve indicates the pace of adoption of any new technology by people.

glossaries.title: Airdrop
glossaries.teaser: A marketing campaign often used in the cryptocurrency space where a specific cryptocurrency or token is distributed to an audience with the aim of attracting new people to the coin or token.

glossaries.title: All-Time High (ATH)
glossaries.teaser: The highest price of a cryptocurrency when looking at how much of a base currency is required to purchase 1 unit of the cryptocurrency.

glossaries.title: Altcoin
glossaries.teaser: All cryptocurrency coins that followed the Bitcoin are referred to as “alternative coins”, or “altcoins”.

glossaries.title: Angel Investor
glossaries.teaser: A high-networth investor that funds companies, usually at their early stages, and usually with their own money.

glossaries.title: Account
glossaries.teaser: An account is basically a wallet that tracks the financial activities of a specific person. The account can track financial activities relating to one asset or multiple assets.

glossaries.title: Anti-Dump/Anti-Dumping Policy
glossaries.teaser: This policy is a set of rules that protects cryptocurrency investors from pump and dump schemes. A pump and dump is when a large number of tokens are purchased by an investor to boost the tok

glossaries.title: Anti-Money Laundering (AML)
glossaries.teaser: International laws that are set to prevent criminal organizations and individuals from laundering money through cryptocurrencies.

glossaries.title: ASIC-resistant
glossaries.teaser: Cryptocurrencies that are ASIC-resistant have a protocol and mining algorithm that are configured in such a way that it is impossible to mine the coin using ASIC machines, or the use of ASIC

glossaries.title: Asynchronous
glossaries.teaser: Events that occur in electronic systems either at the same time or speed, that may happen independent of the main program flow.

glossaries.title: Atomic Swap
glossaries.teaser: The transfer of value from one cryptocurrency to another without the use of an exchange or intermediary.

glossaries.title: AtomicDEX
glossaries.teaser: A cryptocurrency wallet and DEX in one application that can be used for multiple platforms.

glossaries.title: Attack
glossaries.teaser: An attempt made by cyber criminals to break into a cryptosystem.

glossaries.title: Attestation Ledger
glossaries.teaser: An attestation ledger is designed to provide evidence of individual transactions, and is used to “attest” that a transaction took place. Can also be used to prove the authenticity of transact

glossaries.title: Audit
glossaries.teaser: A process undertaken by developers to inspect the underlying code or algorithm of systems and applications.

glossaries.title: Authentication
glossaries.teaser: The process of confirming a user’s identity using passwords, SMS codes, fingerprints, and other forms of ownership proofs before access is granted to sensitive and/or personal information.

glossaries.title: Back Door
glossaries.teaser: A flaw in cipher design that grants access to anyone who discovers or knows the secret.

glossaries.title: Bag
glossaries.teaser: Cryptocurrency slang used to describe a large quantity of a specific cryptocurrency.

glossaries.title: Bandwidth
glossaries.teaser: The maximum amount of data that can be transferred over a network at a given time.

glossaries.title: Beacon Chain
glossaries.teaser: A blockchain that coordinates shard chains, manages staking as well as the registry of validators in a Proof of Stake network.

glossaries.title: Bear Market
glossaries.teaser: A term used to describe a negative trend in prices of a particular market. It is also used in the traditional markets.

glossaries.title: BEP-2 (Binance Chain Tokenization Standard)
glossaries.teaser: A technical standard used for tokens that are built on top of the Binance Chain.

glossaries.title: BEP-20
glossaries.teaser: A Binance Smart Chain token standard with the intention of extending ERC-20.

glossaries.title: BEP-721
glossaries.teaser: A Binance Smart Chain (BSC) token standard that enables the generation of non-fungible tokens (NFTs). BEP-721 is believed to be an extension of ERC-721 - one of the most popular NFT standards

glossaries.title: Beta (Release)
glossaries.teaser: A software pre-release where access to the software is granted to a set number of users and third-party software testers to test it under real-world settings.

glossaries.title: Blind Signature Scheme
glossaries.teaser: A scheme whereby one party allows another party to sign a message without knowing the contents of the message.

glossaries.title: Block
glossaries.teaser: A group of transactions completed during a given time, compiled into a block with a digital fingerprint called a hash.

glossaries.title: Block Cipher
glossaries.teaser: A protocol that encrypts data into blocks.

glossaries.title: Block Explorer
glossaries.teaser: An application that users can make use of to view details of blocks on given blockchains.

glossaries.title: Block Header
glossaries.teaser: A unique identifier for a block on a blockchain. It is hashed on a continuous basis in the Proof of Work mining process.

glossaries.title: Block Reward
glossaries.teaser: The coins awarded to miners for solving the network’s mathematical puzzle required to create a new block on a blockchain.

glossaries.title: Block Size
glossaries.teaser: The block size of a blockchain refers to the amount of data relating to transactions that can be stored in a single block in a blockchain.

glossaries.title: Blockchain
glossaries.teaser: A decentralized digital ledger that comprises a sequence of blocks stored consecutively in a public database. These digital ledgers are the basis for cryptocurrencies.

glossaries.title: Blockchain 1.0
glossaries.teaser: This is the first generation of blockchain technology, and focused on cryptocurrency and decentralization.

glossaries.title: Blockchain 2.0
glossaries.teaser: Building on Blockchain 1.0, Blockchain 2.0 is the next iteration of blockchain technology . This new iteration introduced the concept of the decentralization of business and markets through s

glossaries.title: Blockchain 3.0
glossaries.teaser: The latest iteration of blockchain technology that aims to grow global, institutional, and enterprise adoption.

glossaries.title: Blockchain trilemma
glossaries.teaser: A set of three issues with blockchain technology that currently cannot be solved simultaneously. These problems are the interoperability of blockchains, their usability, and their scalability

glossaries.title: Bridges
glossaries.teaser: A technology that enables the seamless transfer of data or tokens between two blockchain projects.

glossaries.title: Bull Market
glossaries.teaser: A term used to describe a positive trend in prices in a particular market. It is also used in the traditional markets.

glossaries.title: Burning Tokens
glossaries.teaser: The process of burning tokens is when coins or tokens have been purposely and permanently removed from circulation.

glossaries.title: Byzantine Fault Tolerance (BFT)
glossaries.teaser: This is the property of computer systems that enable them to reach consensus regardless if some of the components in the system fail.

glossaries.title: Censorship
glossaries.teaser: The act of altering or prohibiting any speech or writing that is labeled as detrimental to the general public.

glossaries.title: Censorship Resistance
glossaries.teaser: This is the idea that no single party or parties can prevent anyone else from participating in a given network or platform.

glossaries.title: Central Bank
glossaries.teaser: In traditional economies, the central bank is responsible for coming up with and implementing monetary policy, as well as for the regulation of member banks.

glossaries.title: Centralized Exchange (CEX)
glossaries.teaser: A centralized exchange is a type of cryptocurrency exchange platform that is operated, owned, and maintained by a company in a centralized manner.

glossaries.title: Certificate
glossaries.teaser: An electronic document provided by a Certifying Authority that binds information which can be used to identify the owner with a public key.

glossaries.title: Cipher
glossaries.teaser: An algorithm that can be used to encrypt and decrypt data or information.

glossaries.title: Circulating Supply
glossaries.teaser: An approximation of the number of coins that are circulating in the market and being transacted with by users in the market.

glossaries.title: Clipper
glossaries.teaser: An encryption chip used in all encrypted communications. It was developed by the U.S. government and would allow them to essentially eavesdrop after obtaining a warrant.

glossaries.title: Coin Mixer
glossaries.teaser: This is a protocol that mixes up transactions between different cryptocurrency addresses so that linking the transaction with the initial sender and receiver is impossible.

glossaries.title: Cold Storage
glossaries.teaser: Storage solutions that store cryptocurrency offline. These solutions often involve hardware non - custodial wallets, paper wallets, or offline computers.

glossaries.title: Consensus
glossaries.teaser: Achieved when all the participants in the network agree on the order and content of the blocks in the blockchain.

glossaries.title: Consensus Mechanism
glossaries.teaser: This is the underlying technology behind the major functionalities of every blockchain. They are an essential operating feature of all cryptocurrencies.

glossaries.title: Cross-Chain Communication
glossaries.teaser: If enabled between two blockchains, cross-chain communication allows different protocols to verify data and transactions without requiring intervention from a third-party service.

glossaries.title: Crypto Debit Card
glossaries.teaser: A type of debit card that allows cryptocurrency holders to pay for goods and services using their cryptocurrency.

glossaries.title: Cryptocurrencies
glossaries.teaser: Digital currencies that use cryptographic technologies to secure their operation.

glossaries.title: Cryptography
glossaries.teaser: Methods used to make information secure.

glossaries.title: Custodial
glossaries.teaser: Custodian cryptocurrency businesses are cryptocurrency businesses that hold and secure their customer’s funds for as long as the customer uses their services.

glossaries.title: Data Privacy
glossaries.teaser: Refers to the field of data protection and security that handles sensitive data.

glossaries.title: Decentralized API
glossaries.teaser: API services that are able to seamlessly interchange data between blockchains are known as decentralized application programming interfaces, or d APIs.

glossaries.title: Decentralized Applications (dApps)
glossaries.teaser: An application that runs on a decentralized network, like a blockchain network, and does not have a single point of failure.

glossaries.title: Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAO)
glossaries.teaser: This is an organization that is governed by a set of computer-defined rules written on blockchain-based smart contracts.

glossaries.title: Decentralized Exchange (DEX)
glossaries.teaser: A peer-to-peer exchange that cryptocurrency traders can use without the need for an intermediary.

glossaries.title: Decentralized Governance
glossaries.teaser: Procedures through which autonomous and distributed management is carried out for blockchain networks and dApps.

glossaries.title: Decryption
glossaries.teaser: The process of extracting information that has been encrypted.

glossaries.title: DeFi
glossaries.teaser: A movement that proposes alternatives to the centralized, traditional forms of financial services.

glossaries.title: DeFi Aggregator
glossaries.teaser: Brings together trades from multiple DeFi platforms into one place.

glossaries.title: Deflation
glossaries.teaser: The decline in the general level of prices for goods and services in an economy.

glossaries.title: Denial-of-Service (DoS) Attack
glossaries.teaser: A type of attack that aims to temporarily make a computer network or service unavailable to its intended users.

glossaries.title: Deterministic Wallet
glossaries.teaser: A cryptocurrency wallet type in which a single seed is used to create keys and addresses.

glossaries.title: Difficulty
glossaries.teaser: The difficulty associated with validating a new block on a blockchain.

glossaries.title: Digital Asset
glossaries.teaser: Refers to the digital representation of something with value.

glossaries.title: Digital Fingerprint
glossaries.teaser: Similar to digital signature.

glossaries.title: Digital Signature
glossaries.teaser: A value that provides authentication in an electronic document.

glossaries.title: Distributed Consensus
glossaries.teaser: The collective agreement reached among nodes in a network.

glossaries.title: Distributed Key
glossaries.teaser: A key divided into several parts and shared with multiple participants.

glossaries.title: Distributed Ledger
glossaries.teaser: Ledgers in which data is stored within a network of decentralized nodes. It does not necessarily involve a cryptocurrency and can be permissioned or private.

glossaries.title: DYOR
glossaries.teaser: An acronym for Do Your Own Research. Investors are encouraged to do their own due diligence into a project before investing any money in it.

glossaries.title: Encryption
glossaries.teaser: A method through which information can be secured through code and mathematics.

glossaries.title: Epoch
glossaries.teaser: One complete run of the training dataset through a machine learning algorithm.

glossaries.title: ERC-20
glossaries.teaser: Tokens designed and used solely on the Ethereum blockchain.

glossaries.title: ERC-223
glossaries.teaser: An Ethereum token standard that is powered by smart contracts and enables users to securely transfer tokens to a digital wallet.

glossaries.title: ERC-721
glossaries.teaser: A token standard for non-fungible tokens on the Ethereum platform.

glossaries.title: Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM)
glossaries.teaser: A Turing-complete virtual machine that enables execution of code exactly as intended. It is the runtime environment for every Ethereum-based smart contract. Every Ethereum node runs on the EV

glossaries.title: Exchange Traded Fund (ETF)
glossaries.teaser: A security that can track a basket of assets whether they are stocks, bonds, or cryptocurrencies. The security can be traded like a single stock.

glossaries.title: Expiration Date
glossaries.teaser: The expiration date for a certificate or key.

glossaries.title: Faucet
glossaries.teaser: A cryptocurrency reward system usually located on a website or app. The faucet rewards users for completing certain tasks.

glossaries.title: Fiat
glossaries.teaser: A currency that has “legal tender” and is backed by a central government such as the Federal Reserve. It has its own banking system and can take the form of physical cash or be represented el

glossaries.title: Fiat-Pegged Cryptocurrency
glossaries.teaser: A coin, token or asset issued on a blockchain that is linked to a government or bank-issued currency.

glossaries.title: Flash Loan
glossaries.teaser: A transaction in which a specific quantity of liquidity is borrowed and repaid in the same transaction or block.

glossaries.title: FOMO
glossaries.teaser: An acronym, and stands for Fear of Missing Out.

glossaries.title: Forgery
glossaries.teaser: A data item with content that misleads the recipient into believing it came from a different source.

glossaries.title: FUD
glossaries.teaser: An acronym that stands for Fear, Uncertainty, and Doubt. It is a strategy used to influence the perception of certain cryptocurrencies in the market by spreading negative, misleading and fals

glossaries.title: Full Node
glossaries.teaser: Nodes that download the entire history of a blockchain in order to observe and enforce its rules.

glossaries.title: Fungible
glossaries.teaser: In cryptocurrency, fungibility refers to a coin or token’s ability to be replaced by another identical coin or token.

glossaries.title: GameFi
glossaries.teaser: Better known as play-to-earn (P2E), GameFi is a relatively new term in both the gaming and cryptocurrency industries.

glossaries.title: Gas
glossaries.teaser: A term used when transacting on the Ethereum blockchain that refers to a unit of measuring the computational effort of performing transactions, deploying smart contracts, or launching dApps i

glossaries.title: Gems
glossaries.teaser: The term Gem is used to describe a relatively unknown low-cap coin that has immense potential or is grossly undervalued.

glossaries.title: Genesis Block
glossaries.teaser: The first block of data that is processed and validated on a new blockchain. It is also often referred to as block 0 or block 1.

glossaries.title: Gold-Backed Cryptocurrency
glossaries.teaser: A coin or token issued that represents a value of Gold.

glossaries.title: Governance
glossaries.teaser: In the cryptocurrency space, governance is the people or organizations that have decision-making powers regarding the project.

glossaries.title: Governance Token
glossaries.teaser: A token that can be used to vote on decisions that influence an ecosystem.

glossaries.title: Halving
glossaries.teaser: An event whereby the total rewards per confirmed block are halved.

glossaries.title: Hardware Wallet
glossaries.teaser: A cryptocurrency wallet that usually comes in the form of a USB stick.

glossaries.title: Hash
glossaries.teaser: The output result of a hashing algorithm. The hash is a unique, fixed-length string to encrypt and secure a certain selection of arbitrary data.

glossaries.title: Hash Function
glossaries.teaser: Any function that is used to map arbitrary data of arbitrary size to data of a fixed size.

glossaries.title: Hash Power
glossaries.teaser: A unit of measure for the amount of computer power consumed by a network to continuously operate.

glossaries.title: HODL
glossaries.teaser: An investment strategy where a person holds onto an investment for the long term regardless of changing market conditions. The term first made an appearance as a type on a Bitcoin forum, and

glossaries.title: Hot Storage
glossaries.teaser: Refers to the storage of private keys online to allow for quicker access to cryptocurrencies.

glossaries.title: Hot Wallet
glossaries.teaser: A cryptocurrency wallet that is connected to the internet.

glossaries.title: Immutable
glossaries.teaser: A property of blockchain technology that refers to the inability for data on the chain to be altered, especially over extended periods of time.

glossaries.title: Inflation
glossaries.teaser: A general increase in prices and fall in the purchasing value of money.

glossaries.title: Initial Coin Offering (ICO)
glossaries.teaser: An ICO is a type of crowdfunding, or crowdsale, that uses cryptocurrency as a means of raising capital for early-stage companies.

glossaries.title: Initial Exchange Offering (IEO)
glossaries.teaser: A type of crowdfunding where crypto start-ups generate capital by listing through an exchange.

glossaries.title: Initial Game Offering (IGO)
glossaries.teaser: Provide individuals an opportunity to invest in gaming projects at a very early stage. These games generally have a lot of potential and can offer huge returns to investors after their launch

glossaries.title: Internet of Things
glossaries.teaser: Internet of Things, or IoT, is a global interconnected network of devices, sensors and software that are able to collect and exchange data with each other in real-time over the Internet.

glossaries.title: Interoperability
glossaries.teaser: Blockchain-interoperability, or cross-chain interoperability, is the ability to transfer and view data and information across multiple blockchains regardless of what protocol they use.

glossaries.title: Intrinsic Value
glossaries.teaser: When it comes to an asset, its intrinsic value depicts its actual worth based on a complex financial calculation rather than its currency price.

glossaries.title: JavaScript
glossaries.teaser: A powerful, dynamic, lightweight, and advanced programming language. It is mostly used in web-based applications.

glossaries.title: Key
glossaries.teaser: A string of bits that someone can use to encrypt and decrypt data.

glossaries.title: Key Schedule
glossaries.teaser: This is the algorithm that generates the subkeys in a Block Cipher.

glossaries.title: Key Space
glossaries.teaser: A collection of all of the possible keys for a cryptosystem.

glossaries.title: Know Your Customer (KYC)
glossaries.teaser: These are checks that must be completed by cryptocurrency exchanges and platforms in order to verify the identity of their customers.

glossaries.title: Large Cap
glossaries.teaser: Projects and organizations that are well established are called large cap or big cap companies if their market capitalization is $10 billion or above.

glossaries.title: Layer 0
glossaries.teaser: A network framework running beneath the blockchain. In this layer, you’ll find the protocols, connections, hardware, miners, and everything else that forms the foundation of the blockchain ec

glossaries.title: Layer 2
glossaries.teaser: This name is given to scaling solutions that enable high throughput of transactions whilst fully inheriting and maintaining the security of the underlying blockchain that it is built on top o

glossaries.title: Layer-1 Blockchain
glossaries.teaser: A set of solutions that aim to improve the base protocol of a blockchain.

glossaries.title: Ledger
glossaries.teaser: A record of financial transactions where transactions can only be appended and can’t be altered.

glossaries.title: Life Cycle
glossaries.teaser: How long a key can be used to provide adequate security.

glossaries.title: Light Node
glossaries.teaser: These are typically downloaded cryptocurrency wallets that are connected to full nodes to further validate the information that is stored on the blockchain.

glossaries.title: Lightning Network
glossaries.teaser: A Layer-2 protocol that is designed to solve the restricted degree of scalability of the Bitcoin network. It achieves this by speeding up transaction processing speeds.

glossaries.title: Liquidity
glossaries.teaser: Refers to how easily a cryptocurrency can be bought and sold without impacting the overall market price.

glossaries.title: Liquidity Mining
glossaries.teaser: A mechanism or process in which participants provide liquidity to liquidity pools. They then receive rewards based on their share of the total liquidity in the pool. These rewards come in the

glossaries.title: Liquidity Pool
glossaries.teaser: Cryptocurrency assets that are kept to facilitate the trading of trading pairs on decentralized exchanges.

glossaries.title: Liquidity Provider
glossaries.teaser: Decentralized exchange users who fund a liquidity pool with tokens under their possession.

glossaries.title: Mainnet
glossaries.teaser: An independent blockchain with its own network, technology, and protocol.

glossaries.title: Mainnet Swap
glossaries.teaser: This is when a cryptocurrency project is shifted from one blockchain network to another. This mostly happens when the project is shifted to its own native blockchain network.

glossaries.title: Market Capitalization
glossaries.teaser: The total capitalization of a cryptocurrency’s price. It is one of the ways to rank the relative size of a cryptocurrency.

glossaries.title: Masternodes
glossaries.teaser: A masternode is a server that is maintained by its owner. It’s like a full node but with additional functionalities such as annonymizing transactions, clearing transactions, and participating

glossaries.title: Mempool
glossaries.teaser: A node’s collection of all of the unprocessed transactions that it has seen.

glossaries.title: Merkle Tree
glossaries.teaser: A tree structure used in cryptography. In this tree structure, leaf nodes are labeled with the hash of a data block and every non-leaf node is labeled with the cryptographic hash of the label

glossaries.title: MetaMask
glossaries.teaser: An online digital wallet that allows users to manage, transfer and receive Ethereum. It is a browser wallet that has to be installed as a browser extension.

glossaries.title: Metaverse
glossaries.teaser: A digital universe that contains multiple aspects of the real world such as real-time interactions and economies.

glossaries.title: Microtransaction
glossaries.teaser: A very small payment that can be made for goods and services.

glossaries.title: Mining
glossaries.teaser: The process of adding blocks to a Proof of Work blockchain network. It is also the process through which new bitcoin or some altcoins are created.

glossaries.title: Mining Pool
glossaries.teaser: An arrangement where a number of miners can pool their computing power to increase their chances of formulating the next block in the network.

glossaries.title: Mining Reward
glossaries.teaser: The income that miners receive for finding and validating a block.

glossaries.title: Minting
glossaries.teaser: The process of generating new coins using the Proof of Stake mechanism and adding them to the circulating supply.

glossaries.title: Mnemonic Phrase
glossaries.teaser: A list of words used in sequence to restore and access a cryptocurrency wallet.

glossaries.title: Multi-Signature (Multi-Sig)
glossaries.teaser: An added layer of security that requires more than one key to authorize a transaction.

glossaries.title: Network
glossaries.teaser: All the nodes active in a blockchain network at any given time.

glossaries.title: Node
glossaries.teaser: The fundamental unit of a blockchain infrastructure that stores data.

glossaries.title: Nominators
glossaries.teaser: One of the two main actors involved in a blockchain network that uses the Nominated Proof of Stake consensus algorithm.

glossaries.title: Non-Custodial
glossaries.teaser: A non-custodial setup in the blockchain space is one in which private keys are held by the user directly.

glossaries.title: Non-Fungible Token (NFT)
glossaries.teaser: Non-Fungible Token (NFT)

glossaries.title: Nonce
glossaries.teaser: A nonce is an arbitrary number meant to be used only once by a miner when hashing a transaction.

glossaries.title: Off-Chain
glossaries.teaser: Outside of the blockchain network.

glossaries.title: Off-Chain Governance
glossaries.teaser: A form of blockchain governance in which decisions are made informally, away from the blockchain’s primary code base.

glossaries.title: Off-Chain Transaction
glossaries.teaser: Transactions that are processed outside of the blockchain network in order to increase transaction speeds and decrease transaction costs on the network.

glossaries.title: On-Chain
glossaries.teaser: Activity that takes place on the blockchain itself and that is shared with all of the participants in a network.

glossaries.title: On-Chain Governance
glossaries.teaser: A decentralized framework used for organizing and integrating updates/improvements to the blockchain network.

glossaries.title: One Time Password
glossaries.teaser: A password that can only be used once.

glossaries.title: Open Source
glossaries.teaser: A philosophy of participants who believe in the free and open sharing of information in the pursuit of the greater common good.

glossaries.title: Oracles
glossaries.teaser: A blockchain protocol that bridges the gap between the real world and a blockchain network by providing data to smart contracts.

glossaries.title: Paper Wallet
glossaries.teaser: A physical document that contains a user’s private key or seed phrase.

glossaries.title: Parachain
glossaries.teaser: Application-specific data structures that run parallel to each other in the Polkadot network.

glossaries.title: Passive Income
glossaries.teaser: Money produced from investments that do not require active involvement from the investor.

glossaries.title: Password
glossaries.teaser: A key that comes in the form of either a word or a group of characters and allows a user to access an area that is secure.

glossaries.title: Peer-to-Peer (P2P)
glossaries.teaser: Interactions in a distributed network that are decentralized in nature, partitioning tasks or workloads between the peers in the network.

glossaries.title: Peer-to-peer (P2P) Lending
glossaries.teaser: The practice of lending assets in the cryptocurrency space without needing a middleman. Loans made in a P2P lending platform require collateral for the loan from borrowers.

glossaries.title: Permissioned Ledger
glossaries.teaser: A ledger in which only people and organizations requiring access to it have permission to access the ledger.

glossaries.title: Plain Text
glossaries.teaser: Data that has not been encrypted yet.

glossaries.title: Play-to-Earn
glossaries.teaser: A business model that supports the notion of an open economy and gives financial rewards to players who bring value to the metaverse.

glossaries.title: Pre-Sale
glossaries.teaser: The sale of cryptocurrency to specific investors ahead of it going public.

glossaries.title: Private Blockchain
glossaries.teaser: A type of blockchain in which only a single organization has authority over the network.

glossaries.title: Private/Secret Key
glossaries.teaser: A code generated in the asymmetric-key encryption process. It is paired with a public key and is used in decrypting information hashed with the public key.

glossaries.title: Proof of Attendance Protocol (POAP)
glossaries.teaser: POAP refers to a business offering that uses Ethereum’s ERC-721 NFT protocol to ascribe individuals a unique, non-fungible blockchain-based identifier that only the person can access.

glossaries.title: Proof of Stake (PoS)
glossaries.teaser: A blockchain consensus mechanism that randomly selects validators based on the amount of native cryptocurrency they stake.

glossaries.title: Proof of Work (PoW)
glossaries.teaser: Another type of blockchain consensus model that requires nodes in the network to solve computationally-intensive puzzles to validate transactions and create new blocks.

glossaries.title: Protocol
glossaries.teaser: A set of rules that define interactions on a network. These protocols usually involve some sort of consensus, transaction validation, and network participation on the blockchain.

glossaries.title: Pseudonymous
glossaries.teaser: Writing under a false name, such as “Satoshi Nakamoto”.

glossaries.title: Public Address
glossaries.teaser: A cryptographic hash of a public key, allowing the user to use it as an address to request for payment.

glossaries.title: Public Blockchain
glossaries.teaser: A blockchain that can be accessed by anyone.

glossaries.title: Public Key
glossaries.teaser: A series of alphanumeric characters used to encrypt plain text messages into ciphertext.

glossaries.title: Pyramid Scheme
glossaries.teaser: A type of scam with a hierarchical top-down structure.

glossaries.title: QR Code
glossaries.teaser: A machine-readable label that encodes information into a graphical black-and-white pattern.

glossaries.title: Quantum Computing
glossaries.teaser: A computer that harnesses phenomena from quantum mechanics in order to perform much more efficient computations than their older, classical counterparts.

glossaries.title: Rage-quit
glossaries.teaser: The process of a member of a DAO exiting part or all of their stake, leaving with a proportional share of the assets in the DAO’s treasury, and quitting their participation.

glossaries.title: Raiden Network
glossaries.teaser: An off-chain scaling solution that aims to achieve low-fee, near-instant and scalable payments on the Ethereum blockchain.

glossaries.title: Rank
glossaries.teaser: The relative position of a cryptocurrency in terms of market capitalization.

glossaries.title: Random Number Generator
glossaries.teaser: An algorithm or device that generates a sequence of numbers that has no set pattern.

glossaries.title: Rebase
glossaries.teaser: A token designed to adjust its circulating supply automatically according to price fluctuations.

glossaries.title: Recover Seed
glossaries.teaser: A cryptographically derived security code that is usually represented as a list of random words. The list is between 12 and 14 words long.

glossaries.title: Reusable Password
glossaries.teaser: A password that can be used repeatedly.

glossaries.title: Running Time
glossaries.teaser: The time it takes for a specific algorithm to run as a function.

glossaries.title: Salt
glossaries.teaser: An arbitrary value attached to a password before hash authentication, and is unique to a specific user.
glossaries.description: An arbitrary value attached to a password before hash authentication, and is unique to a specific user.

glossaries.title: Satoshi
glossaries.teaser: The smallest unit of bitcoin with a value of 0.00000001 BTC.
glossaries.description: The smallest unit of bitcoin with a value of 0.00000001 BTC.

glossaries.title: Satoshi Nakamoto
glossaries.teaser: A pseudonym used to describe the individual or group of individuals that created Bitcoin.
glossaries.description: A pseudonym used to describe the individual or group of individuals that created Bitcoin.

glossaries.title: Scaling Problem
glossaries.teaser: When referring to blockchain technology, the scaling problem has to do with a blockchain’s low transaction throughput and ability to achieve fast, low-cost transactions.
glossaries.description: When referring to blockchain technology, the scaling problem has to do with a blockchain’s low transaction throughput and ability to achieve fast, low-cost transactions.

glossaries.title: Second-Layer Solutions
glossaries.teaser: A set of solutions that are built on top of a public blockchain that aim to extend its scalability and efficiency.
glossaries.description: A set of solutions that are built on top of a public blockchain that aim to extend its scalability and efficiency.

glossaries.title: Secret Key
glossaries.teaser: A crypto key with a symmetric algorithm that is used for both encrypting and decrypting the same data.
glossaries.description: A crypto key with a symmetric algorithm that is used for both encrypting and decrypting the same data.

glossaries.title: Seed Phrase
glossaries.teaser: The single starting point when deriving keys for a deterministic wallet.
glossaries.description: The single starting point when deriving keys for a deterministic wallet.

glossaries.title: Session Key
glossaries.teaser: A key that is discarded after being used for a single session or message.
glossaries.description: A key that is discarded after being used for a single session or message.

glossaries.title: Shard
glossaries.teaser: A portion of a blockchain network that has been split into multiple shards, which has its own data.
glossaries.description: A portion of a blockchain network that has been split into multiple shards, which has its own data.

glossaries.title: Shielded Transaction
glossaries.teaser: A transaction that takes place between two shielded blockchain addresses.
glossaries.description: A transaction that takes place between two shielded blockchain addresses.

glossaries.title: Side Chain
glossaries.teaser: A blockchain that runs in parallel to a primary blockchain. There is a two-way link between a primary chain and side chain.
glossaries.description: A blockchain that runs in parallel to a primary blockchain. There is a two-way link between a primary chain and side chain.

glossaries.title: Smart Contract
glossaries.teaser: A computer protocol that is intended to facilitate, verify or enforce a contract on the blockchain without third parties.
glossaries.description: A computer protocol that is intended to facilitate, verify or enforce a contract on the blockchain without third parties.

glossaries.title: Sniffing
glossaries.teaser: An attack which copies the content of network messages with the goal of obtaining valuable information such as passwords.
glossaries.description: An attack which copies the content of network messages with the goal of obtaining valuable information such as passwords.

glossaries.title: Splitting
glossaries.teaser: A process that makes it difficult for an attacker to reconstruct a crypto key by dividing the crypto key into two parts.
glossaries.description: A process that makes it difficult for an attacker to reconstruct a crypto key by dividing the crypto key into two parts.

glossaries.title: Stablecoin
glossaries.teaser: A cryptocurrency with extremely low volatility when compared to traditional cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin and Ethereum. Some stablecoins are also pegged to a real-world commodity like Gold or
glossaries.description: A cryptocurrency with extremely low volatility when compared to traditional cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin and Ethereum. Some stablecoins are also pegged to a real-world commodity like Gold or a fiat currency such as USD.

glossaries.title: Symmetric Cipher
glossaries.teaser: A cipher that uses the same key to both encrypt and decrypt data.
glossaries.description: A cipher that uses the same key to both encrypt and decrypt data.

glossaries.title: Testnet
glossaries.teaser: An alternative blockchain used for testing by developers.
glossaries.description: An alternative blockchain used for testing by developers.

glossaries.title: Tokenize
glossaries.teaser: The process of turning real-world assets into something of digital value, called a token. This often opens up the possibility for fractionalized ownership of the asset to different owners.
glossaries.description: The process of turning real-world assets into something of digital value, called a token. This often opens up the possibility for fractionalized ownership of the asset to different owners.

glossaries.title: Tokenomics
glossaries.teaser: The science of token economy which consists of a set of rules that governs a cryptocurrency’s issuance and supply.
glossaries.description: The science of token economy which consists of a set of rules that governs a cryptocurrency’s issuance and supply.

glossaries.title: Tor
glossaries.teaser: A decentralized network that anonymizes a user’s web traffic by encrypting and routing it through a series of relays before it reaches its final destination.
glossaries.description: A decentralized network that anonymizes a user’s web traffic by encrypting and routing it through a series of relays before it reaches its final destination.

glossaries.title: Transmission Control Protocol
glossaries.teaser: An internet protocol used to provide a reliable connection between a client and a server.
glossaries.description: An internet protocol used to provide a reliable connection between a client and a server.

glossaries.title: Transport Mode
glossaries.teaser: An ESP mode that encrypts data but not the original IP addresses.
glossaries.description: An ESP mode that encrypts data but not the original IP addresses.

glossaries.title: Truffle
glossaries.teaser: Acts as a development environment and a testing framework for blockchains using EVM, and is a widely used tool for blockchain application development.
glossaries.description: Acts as a development environment and a testing framework for blockchains using EVM, and is a widely used tool for blockchain application development.

glossaries.title: Tunnel Mode
glossaries.teaser: An ESP mode that encrypts data and IP addresses.
glossaries.description: An ESP mode that encrypts data and IP addresses.

glossaries.title: Utility Token
glossaries.teaser: Tokens designed specifically to be able to help people use something.
glossaries.description: Tokens designed specifically to be able to help people use something.

glossaries.title: Vulnerability
glossaries.teaser: A weakness in security that could allow an opponent to attack and penetrate a cryptosystem.
glossaries.description: A weakness in security that could allow an opponent to attack and penetrate a cryptosystem.

glossaries.title: Wide Area Network
glossaries.teaser: A group of host computers and sites that are connected across a wide geographic area through a network.
glossaries.description: A group of host computers and sites that are connected across a wide geographic area through a network.

pages.name: Introduction
pages.title: Introduction
pages.details:
Our goal is to educate the masses on the exciting potential of blockchain and cryptocurrency technology. Here, you'll find several multilingual articles covering every aspect of blockchain and cryptocurrency technology - ranging from computer security to economics. 
 
We know that it can be daunting to learn something new. So, this guide will give you a gentle introduction to some of the key concepts that will help you kick-start your journey into the revolutionary world of blockchain technology.



Let's get started.



What is a cryptocurrency?


A cryptocurrency is basically like a sort of digital cash. You can use it to pay for that new T-shirt you've been eyeing, pay for a night out with your friends, or even pay for your travel and accommodation when you go on holiday. Since a cryptocurrency is digital, it can be sent to friends and family across the globe.

 

However, the way cryptocurrency is transferred worldwide is not like any of the traditional methods we know, like PayPal. It's a lot more interesting!

 

What separates cryptocurrency from traditional payment gateways is that no single organization owns the cryptocurrency payment gateway. So, when you want to spend funds or send money, you don't need to ask an organization to transfer it for you on your behalf. Instead, you, your friends, and thousands of others can act as your own bank by running some free software. When you run this software, your computer connects directly with other people's computers. So, the need for a middleman is completely removed.

 

You don't need to sign up on a website or open an account to get started using a cryptocurrency. Instead, you can just download one of the many applications available on your smartphone. You can then start sending and receiving cryptocurrency almost immediately.


Why is it called a cryptocurrency?


A cryptocurrency is a combination of cryptography and currency. This is why it is called a cryptocurrency. It's a revolutionary new form of digital cash that uses advanced math to secure your funds so that nobody else can spend them.

It isn't really necessary to understand all of this since the applications that you download will handle all of the complexities in the background. You won't even know what is happening in the underlying layer of these applications.

If you do want to learn more about the cryptography side of cryptocurrency, then take a look at some of our articles:


Articles
